review_preview: This was a really interesting place. The walls are adorned with some stunning pictures of bullfighters through the ages both inside and outside the ring. In fact I wouldn't have been surprised if one walked in wearing all  the garb and regalia whilst I was...
review_full: This was a really interesting place. The walls are adorned with some stunning pictures of bullfighters through the ages both inside and outside the ring. In fact I wouldn't have been surprised if one walked in wearing all the garb and regalia whilst I was having dinner. The food was beautifully cooked in proper Spanish style and the service was efficient, extremely polite and attentive. I was told that Hemmingway used to frequent the place in the day, so I guess there need be no further recommendation as to the quality on offer.

review_preview: We ate here three years ago and enjoyed the ambience and food so much that we decided to return on this trip. It was as though we were in a time warp. Nothing had changed. The décor was the same; the lighting was the same;...
review_full: We ate here three years ago and enjoyed the ambience and food so much that we decided to return on this trip. It was as though we were in a time warp. Nothing had changed. The décor was the same; the lighting was the same; the waiters were the same. Of course this is a good thing, since we like this place as it is. One imagines it has always been as it is now since it opened in 1941. We enjoyed an excellent melon with jamon appetizer, a plate of clams in “marinera” sauce (not at all like Italian marinara sauce; this sauce doesn’t seem to have much tomato in it), and a plate of oxtail stew. Everything was simply delicious. The waiter was attentive, somewhat formal, though friendly, and unobtrusive. We were there for lunch on both occasions, arriving shortly after they opened at 1:30PM. On neither occasion was the place particularly crowded, just nice and relaxed. If I was in Madrid I’d have lunch there today.

review_preview: If you truely want an authentic experience in Madrid you must go here. My boyfriend and I went for dinner and everything was perfect. The food was amazing, and despite speaking no Spanish, and the waiters speaking very little English, we recieved amazing service. The...
review_full: If you truely want an authentic experience in Madrid you must go here. My boyfriend and I went for dinner and everything was perfect. The food was amazing, and despite speaking no Spanish, and the waiters speaking very little English, we recieved amazing service. The waiters seemed happy to help, excited to provide us a wonderful meal, and were legitmately proud of what they were serving. The portions were large and everything was excellent, from starters to desserts. We started with croquettes of chicken and ham, then had the ox-tail (perfect!) and fish (also amazing!), and finally finshed with the flan and Leche de Frido (or something similar... basically fried milk covered in sugar and cinnamon). It is so good we are considering going again tomorrow. Def recommend!!

review_full: Many tourists pack into Mercado San Miguel, and yet directly across the street is this small family owned place. Authentic good local food at good prices. It may not have the polish of the more touristy places---but this is true spanish food and atmosphere. I live in Madrid and every time I visit I am shocked that so many tourists are across from this place and yet it sits half empty. It should be packed. A local food tour company (Devour) even did a Youtube video selecting this place as having the BEST Tortilla in Madrid. After you finish the mediocre overpriced food at San Miguel, walk over to this place--Grab a seat at the bar and experience a real local gem.

title_review: Gorgeous restaurant, delicious food, wonderful and friendly staff
review_preview: I have been to this lovely restaurant before with friends of my parents, and when my mother and her lady friends decided to visit me I thought this place would be perfect and I was right! We were tight for time so we were in...
review_full: I have been to this lovely restaurant before with friends of my parents, and when my mother and her lady friends decided to visit me I thought this place would be perfect and I was right! We were tight for time so we were in the informal part of the restaurant (previously I had been in the lovely dining room) which was cosy and lively. I decided to order sharing dishes for us all including croquetas, gambas, asparagus, bull's tail and piglet. All delicious. We ordered wine (ribera and albariño) by the glass and it was fab. The entire meal came to €25 per head including two glasses of wine each. Last but certainly not least, the service is WONDERFUL. The staff are presided over by a man whom I take to be the owner who is a dead ringer for King Felipe! What's not to like?!

review_preview: You have to book to be sure of a table! At 8.45pm all is quiet .... The big dining room empty..... Then it all starts! The diners pile in, groups of locals in for dinner. It's busy, slightly crushed and the food's sensational.Huge platters...
review_full: You have to book to be sure of a table! At 8.45pm all is quiet .... The big dining room empty..... Then it all starts! The diners pile in, groups of locals in for dinner. It's busy, slightly crushed and the food's sensational. Huge platters piled high with seafood; prawns of all sizes, various crabs, percebes which look like dead men's fingers! Wooden plates of octopus, fresh hake beautifully cooked, plates of pardon peppers roasted in oil and salted ..... All fabulous, fresh and delicious. For 3 with a couple of bottles of wine, the bill was about £100. Highly recommended.

review_preview: Prior to going to this restaurant, you need to be aware that it is a very crouded restaurant, tables very close to each other and no reservations allowed, so you will be sitted on a first come first serve basis, so  if you go on...
review_full: Prior to going to this restaurant, you need to be aware that it is a very crouded restaurant, tables very close to each other and no reservations allowed, so you will be sitted on a first come first serve basis, so if you go on weekends be aware you will most likely have to wait and be very close to the next table. If you can look pass all this, menu has fantastic seafood plates, such as garlic clams, oysters and hake, which we enjoyed very much. Thye have a fomous seafood platter, for either 2 or 4 people filled with shirps, crabs, crayfish, etc. which most tables were having, so if you are into getting your hands dirty this is the place. Overall if your are looking for a authentic seafood place near Madrid City Center, Ribeira Do Mino will not dissapoint.

review_preview: My hubby tasked me with finding a restaurant in Madrid to enjoy a seafood lunch, we weren't disappointed, in fact he is still considering if this was his best meal ever! Don't bother with the menu, simply order the house special of the mariscada para...
review_full: My hubby tasked me with finding a restaurant in Madrid to enjoy a seafood lunch, we weren't disappointed, in fact he is still considering if this was his best meal ever! Don't bother with the menu, simply order the house special of the mariscada para dos, with a bottle of white wine and pimientos de padrón. We couldn't finish the mountain of seafood that was delivered to our table, there were shrimps, prawns, cray fish, goose barnacles and crab galore. There's also half a loaf on the table with lemon mayonnaise and fresh lemon to dress the seafood. Finger licking fabulous. It was also a Tuesday lunchtime, this restaurant can see 200+ people and there were only 2 tables vacant.

title_review: Fresh seafood platters at reasonable price
review_preview: We read about Ribeira Do Mino and decided to take a look during one of our walking tour. Saw the crowd and so we booked for lunch next day. We ordered a seafood platter suitable for 4 adults and some octopus dish. This mountain of...
review_full: We read about Ribeira Do Mino and decided to take a look during one of our walking tour. Saw the crowd and so we booked for lunch next day. We ordered a seafood platter suitable for 4 adults and some octopus dish. This mountain of shellfish came out and was stacked with shrimp, prawns, crab, barnacles and some other shell fish. The seafood was served with nice warm buns and slices of bread with butter to provide some carb. My family love seafood, we really enjoyed the shell fish except the barnacles which is our first time trying it and did not like them. We requested the waiter to change the barnacles to prawn instead. The shellfish was just boiled and serve cold. Overall, we had a good fresh cheap seafood lunch which cost us less than €50. The restaurant was very popular among the Spaniards and is always super crowded. If you intend to have a meal there, you either come early or make a reservation. For all seafood lovers when you visit Madrid, do not miss this restaurant.

review_preview: This is our favourite place in Madrid. We arrived late on our first night and stumbled across Alhambra whilst out for a walk. We were attracted by the authentic appearance and as it looked busy. We decided to sit at the bar for a couple...
review_full: This is our favourite place in Madrid.  We arrived late on our first night and stumbled across Alhambra whilst out for a walk. We were attracted by the authentic appearance and as it looked busy.  We decided to sit at the bar for a couple of drinks and immediately felt at ease. The place was buzzing with a great atmosphere. Our first drinks came accompanied by free tapas, plus our second and third! We then thought we’d better order some tapas and were glad we did. A plate of anchovies and a plate of peppers with tuna quickly arrived and were quickly despatched. Fabulous and plenty for 2. The service is very friendly and efficient. The staff never seem to stop. When we asked for the bill, 2 free glasses of wine appeared. Very much appreciated. We’ve been back every day now! Alhambra has 2 separate parts, next door to each other and both are great. Highly recommended.

title_review: Bustling seafood restaurant popular with locals

The platters feature a big mound of various sized shrimp, along with crab legs, claws, and other shellfish. At our first lunch we also ordered the grilled sole which was absolutely wonderful. Regrettably, at our second lunch, it was not available nor was any other fish with the exception of hake which we enjoyed, but we had hoped for a large selection of grilled fish.

title_review: Disappointing Christmas Eve Dinner - overpriced and impersonal!
review_preview: Really disappointed with our Christmas Eve dinner here.   We were excited to go as the venue had been recommended online by a Madrid foodie website.   There were several courses and all of them disappointing.   The wait staff were overwhelmed by the number of diners and...
review_full: Really disappointed with our Christmas Eve dinner here. We were excited to go as the venue had been recommended online by a Madrid foodie website. There were several courses and all of them disappointing. The wait staff were overwhelmed by the number of diners and the food was very ordinary, banged down in front of you and felt mass-produced. Croquettes were "grey" and mushy (no crispiness here), the main beef course was lukewarm and barely cooked (think raw in parts), the wine was ordinary and all in all, hugely disappointing for almost Euros 200 for 2 people - which we had to pay in advance. Next time we will take our chances and find one of the more charming, local eateries available. We appreciated that it was Christmas Eve and a lot of places get booked up, hence our advance booking. But there was absolutely nothing to recommend the place.

Go ahead and take the leap, you won’t regret it!

review_preview: After reading a bunch of good reviews about the restaurant Alhambra, we decided to give it a try.We went there around lunch time in March, we were greeted and seated quickly.We ordered a bottle of white wine, seafood paella and Gambas. They brought...
review_full: After reading a bunch of good reviews about the restaurant Alhambra, we decided to give it a try. We went there around lunch time in March, we were greeted and seated quickly. We ordered a bottle of white wine, seafood paella and Gambas.  They brought the bread with some kind of tiny fish on top of it while we were waiting for our main course. They were very tasty. Paella was more than very good, my husband totally loved it. The rice was a little hard, but I have heard that is the way the Spanish paella should be.  OK...let us talk about the Gambas. I thought it would be a couple of Gambas just like the Spanish restaurant in the US. They surely surprised us when they put the plate down.  The plate was completely full! The red cooked giant Spanish Gambas were piled on the entire big plate. They looked so lovely. We did not expect an order that big.  Oh boy…they tasted great! We both enjoyed them. We really wish we could try the dessert, but we were completely full.  The check amount was €32. It covered a bottle of wine, paella, plus Gambas.  The restaurant location is good, service was good, food was GREAT and price was GREAT! It was definitely a very authentic Spanish good restaurant.

title_review: One of my favourite restaurants in Madrid
review_preview: It´s been the greatest discovery of my trip to Spain! I´ve been taking my GF to different restaurants all over the place and this one was without any doubt the best one! First of all I´d like to recommend all tourists here to download an...
review_full: It´s been the greatest discovery of my trip to Spain! I´ve been taking my GF to different restaurants all over the place and this one was without any doubt the best one! First of all I´d like to recommend all tourists here to download an app called El Tenedor because if you do so you may get a 50% discount as I did! To be able to obtain this discount the only thing you must do is to book a table through this app (the discounts may change over time). I booked a table for 3 for lunch on a weekday and we ordered wine, beer and several tapas. The tapas were mollejas, croquetas de mejillón, chipirones encebollados, rabo de toro y verduras a la plancha. Everything was mouth watering! The service was attentive, friendly and helpful and what to say about their typical dessert the jabón! A white chocolate mousse with essence of violet and lemon foam! I´ll defo go back here! 10/10. A satisfied customer.

title_review: Great choice on Calle Cava Baja
review_preview: Incredibly good food, carefully prepared, and nicely presented.  Our table was in a small courtyard, somewhat removed from the tapas bar, so it was quiet and sedate, and gave the waiter the opportunity to talk with us about the menu and the wine choices.  My...
review_full: Incredibly good food, carefully prepared, and nicely presented. Our table was in a small courtyard, somewhat removed from the tapas bar, so it was quiet and sedate, and gave the waiter the opportunity to talk with us about the menu and the wine choices. My wife and I had a bottle of excellent wine (at a great price) and shared several plates: A salad piled high with just fresh tomatoes (5 different varieties), a main dish of sirloin medallions on melted goat cheese, and grilled vegetables (onions, leeks, eggplant, zucchini, mushrooms, red and yellow peppers.) We had a very rich chocolate dessert, ordinarily not what we would order, but this was Madrid, after all, and the dessert was sublime (they called it, of all things, a chocolate cream “airbag” — clearly something was lost in translation). It’s definitely a place we would return to if we get back to Madrid.

title_review: The Best Tortilla I've Ever Had
review_preview: I'm a vegetarian living in Spain, which means I eat a lot of Spanish tortilla. A lot. More than I'd like. I never get tired of this one. It's the best in Madrid. It's creamy and soft on the inside and perfectly salty. If you're...
review_full: I'm a vegetarian living in Spain, which means I eat a lot of Spanish tortilla. A lot. More than I'd like. I never get tired of this one. It's the best in Madrid. It's creamy and soft on the inside and perfectly salty. If you're at the very cool Mercado San Miguel, have some vermut and burrata inside, then step outside and come to the very unassuming Bar Cerveriz for your tortilla. (It's on the side that is facing the paella booth in the market). For the uninitiated, Spanish tortilla (or tortilla de patata) is just egg, potato, and sometimes onion. One serving of tortilla is 3.50 euros. The owners of this bar are from Austurias (a region in the north of Spain) and if you get a small glass of cider, they'll pour it for you in the Austrian way (from way up high).

title_review: Excellent tortilla. Wonderful service. Love this place.
review_preview: Our colleagues recommended this bar as a must-visit for tapas and especially the tortilla. We were not disappointed. High quality wine, delicious tinto de verano, excellent tortilla and jamon Iberico. Very warm  and helpful staff. The proprietor was very friendly, explained to us a lot...
review_full: Our colleagues recommended this bar as a must-visit for tapas and especially the tortilla. We were not disappointed. High quality wine, delicious tinto de verano, excellent tortilla and jamon Iberico. Very warm and helpful staff. The proprietor was very friendly, explained to us a lot of things we didn't know about Spanish cuisine, the difference between jamon Serrano and jamon Iberico, the difference between sangria and tinto de verano, he showed us the typical wine used for tinto de verano, he told us all about Galicia, which is where he is from, and when we ordered several plates while seated at the bar, he dragged over a table to place next to us to accommodate the food. Definitely a highlight of our trip and glad we didn't waste our time at the mercado across the street.  It's very non descript from the outside and very small inside. We actually walked all the way around the square one time looking for it but it was worth seeking out.

title_review: Looking for the best tortilla de patata in Madrid
review_preview: I am on a mission to find the best tortilla de patata in Madrid and provide an unbiased review about the bars and restaurants that serve them. I have been to Sylkar, El Meson de la Tortilla de Gabino, Juana la Loca, and Bodega de...
review_full: I am on a mission to find the best tortilla de patata in Madrid and provide an unbiased review about the bars and restaurants that serve them. I have been to Sylkar, El Meson de la Tortilla de Gabino, Juana la Loca, and Bodega de La Ardosa, and Cerveriz and tried their regular tortilla de patata. This was a little bit of a letdown, especially since outside the restaurant they posted a survey advertising that they have the best tortilla in town (comparing it to some of the other restaurants I have visited), and I have to say it was not the best that I tried. Don't get me wrong, its still a good tortilla, but I didn't think it was as good as they say. The overall flavor was good, but a bit too eggy for me. The potatoes were a good texture and it's a good value for your euro. This is probably the most "traditional" of the tortillas that I tried and I'd recommend that you try it so you have a basis for what other tortillas are out there, and who knows, maybe you will find this one to be your favorite.

title_review: Outstanding, authentic, family-run, friendly eats and drinks
review_preview: Across the road from the meat market that is the uber-tourist Meat Market is an almost forgotten, outstanding traditional family tapas bar.  You can miss the place, because of the nondescript frontage. We found it accidentally having decided that the Meat Market was a great...
review_full: Across the road from the meat market that is the uber-tourist Meat Market is an almost forgotten, outstanding traditional family tapas bar. You can miss the place, because of the nondescript frontage. We found it accidentally having decided that the Meat Market was a great place only to be jostled and hassled by other tourists. A family run operation since 1969, the wine selection is broad and excellent and displayed fully behind the bar. The tortilla is the best in Spain and the Callos a la Madrileña is superb.

review_preview: While traveling in Madrid after a week of Vaughantown, as an anglo teacher in their program, my traveling companion and I spent several days in Madrid at Calle Cava Baja in a rented flat.  Across the street we found this restaurant, by chance, and walked...
review_full: While traveling in Madrid after a week of Vaughantown, as an anglo teacher in their program, my traveling companion and I spent several days in Madrid at Calle Cava Baja in a rented flat. Across the street we found this restaurant, by chance, and walked in on Tuesday evening about 10:30 for dinner. A marvelous experience awaited us. The restaurant is in the location of a former soap factory, and when renovation was under way, the original city walls of the city were found underneath. Now, you can dine on a glass floor over the city walls, a truly unique experience. The service attendants were excellent and the food some of the best we found in our month long trip in Spain. The bbq ribs were cooked three days at a low temperature and the sauce with them so good, we literally scraped the dish with bread. The most unusual desert I have experience anywhere in the world was served. I translate the name to "Soap and Suds"...the appearance of a bar of soap and soap suds...and it was as great as the remainder of the meal!! Do go for an evening of entertainment, friendship and great food. It was so good we had two locals meet us the next night for a feast...they had not been before, but I am sure they will return!!!

review_preview: If you go by too quickly you will miss La Antonita on Cava Baja street (Cava Baja is right behind the Plaza Mayor). It is inside a small boutique hotel, the Posada del Dragon (Dragon's Inn). The restaurant serves lunch and dinner and has a...
review_full: If you go by too quickly you will miss La Antonita on Cava Baja street (Cava Baja is right behind the Plaza Mayor). It is inside a small boutique hotel, the Posada del Dragon (Dragon's Inn). The restaurant serves lunch and dinner and has a full bar. I had lunch there and it was a very reasonable "prix fix" lunch (as it customary Monday through Friday from 2:00pm to 4:00pm in most restaurants around Madrid). There are various price levels (depending on how many dishes you want to try), the portions are slightly bigger than a tasting menu, but nonetheless delicious. Try the "19th Century"(Style) potato salad, or the oxtail rolls...but you MUST try the cutest dessert ever, the Antonita "soap"!

review_preview: We went to several restaurants during our visit to Madrid and this is the only one I feel obliged to write a review about. We went there for lunch and were immediately struck by the natural friendliness of the wait staff (those in other restaurants...
review_full: We went to several restaurants during our visit to Madrid and this is the only one I feel obliged to write a review about. We went there for lunch and were immediately struck by the natural friendliness of the wait staff (those in other restaurants in Madrid can be rather brusque) who were all too happy to recommend things. Tucked nicely away slightly off the main busy streets surrounding Plaza Mayor but close enough to be easily accessible. The interior decor was very clean and simple, and added to the overall ambience of the place. Food was excellent and despite being essentially spanish, was very different to what we'd been having the rest of the trip. Particularly recommended is the crispy oxtail which almost every table seemed to be having!

review_preview: If you are in Madrid this is one of the places you have to eat at. They prepare the typical tapas found all over Spain but give it a gourmet touch taking them to a whole new level!A not so known wine selection, but...
review_full: If you are in Madrid this is one of the places you have to eat at. They prepare the typical tapas found all over Spain but give it a gourmet touch taking them to a whole new level! A not so known wine selection, but do not let this scare you off. I assure you will be surprised by the quality of the wines the carry. Which makes the whole experience more interesting.  I went with my family and there was not 1 dish which did not fascinate us. Literally one of the best meals I have had in my life.  To top everything off the attention that you get is amazing. I would even dare to say that it is the best you will find in all of Spain. Extremely kind staff and highly attentive waiters will guide you through the menu and give you historical data from the place where the restaurant is located and show you the ancient ruins it has.  If you want a nice night out and want to have amazing food don't think twice about coming here.

So very good, but it was huge and you can split it easily with someone at your table. The inside was a little rowdy, but we were by the door, so was more background noise, I kind of liked that. review_preview: We booked up on a rainy evening in September after many days of 35C+ heat. A rather unassuming entrance part of the boutique hotel La Posada Del Dragon. The menu included a couple of fixed price Tapas options which took a lot of the roulette...
review_full: We booked up on a rainy evening in September after many days of 35C+ heat. A rather unassuming entrance part of the boutique hotel La Posada Del Dragon. The menu included a couple of fixed price Tapas options which took a lot of the roulette out of the Tapas ordering process - we went for two fixed price options and a side of mixed roasted vegetables. The food was really interesting, full of flavours and well presented. The portion sizes were right for us as at the end of the Tapas courses we felt pretty full. Just enough room after a requested time gap to share a dessert. Plenty of good wines by the glass to try out a number of Spanish wines. What took the restaurant to 5 stars was the service - everything explained as well as possible to two non Spanish speakers, attentive but not over bearing. I particularly wanted to try some Pedro Ximenez sherry with my dessert but was initially advised that they had run out - however the waiter went out and got a bottle from another restaurant when he saw my disappointment - service above and beyond! Price for the meal represented good value given the quality and I would definitely go again next time in Madrid.

Unfortunately this tainted our experience.  It was redeemed slightly by the lovely waitress who served us, with great recommendations.  Overall very delicious food, just tainted by an unnecessary head waiter.

Sadly by the time the ribs arrived, i could only manage one. 4 people could have eaten this easily.  Everybody elses food looked great too.  Beautiful restaurant with Roman ruins under the floor. The total bill including a beer, fresh lemonade and 3 glasses wine came to €50 . (With the discount). Obviously not the cheapest of meals, but clearly fine dining. Have been ripped off before for poor meals at not much less. Its very close to centre of town/ plaza Mayor.

title_review: A very good kitchen with a few minor hiccups in the front of the house
review_preview: We chose this restaurant based on location and the 50% off offer for booking through TripAdvisor.  We did not look closely to note the details that this offer was on food only and not applicable to Chefs Selection section of the menu.  Still a good...
review_full: We chose this restaurant based on location and the 50% off offer for booking through TripAdvisor. We did not look closely to note the details that this offer was on food only and not applicable to Chefs Selection section of the menu. Still a good savings. We tried the two croquetas on the menu, both of which were quite tasty! I had the Hake that came with ratatouille, both more than pleased the palate. The two deserts we tried was were the cuisine really shined...particularly in the white chocolate mousse, which I woudl describe more like a white chocolate ice cream accompanied by an interesting and impressive lemon foam. We also tried the Meille with quince...yummy! The hiccups included a bit of confusion in finding our reservation which we'd made about 15-20 minutes prior. We had to call up TripAdvisor on our cellphone and re-enter the reservation prior to being seated although we arrived fairly early, (~8:30pm, which by Madrid dinner time is early...many dinner restaurants are just starting to see their dinners begining about 9pm), Another interesting note was that the litre of sangria came with so much ice that it only provided about 2 to 3 comparable sized servings of the individual glasses of sangria. At 15euro for the litre and only 3.50 euro for a large glass serving, just order by the glass.  Bottom line, I'd recommend a visit if you make a reservation through TripAdvisor to enjoy a food discount but come prepared to show the reservation on your cell phone. Read more at rainaroundtheworld.com

review_preview: Upon arriving, you choose to eat in the dining room which is in the back of the restaurant, or in front where they serve tapas.  As this was to be the main meal of the day, we chose the dining room. No surprise that early...
review_full: Upon arriving, you choose to eat in the dining room which is in the back of the restaurant, or in front where they serve tapas. As this was to be the main meal of the day, we chose the dining room. No surprise that early on a Monday afternoon it was quite empty. We ordered the roast suckling pig, the monkfish, and red peppers stuffed with cod. I started with a cup of gazpacho. The food was wonderful, but beware if you're watching your calories because everything was super rich! The stuffed peppers were decadent, and practically swimming in clarified butter. The suckling pig was wonderful. The gazpacho was fantastic and very authentic. And the atmosphere was also delightful, rather opulent with the walls covered with interesting photos of the owner with various famous people dining there.  I have to say that the service we were given was truly exceptional! Our very friendly and attentive waiter made sure that everything was perfect. He happily prepared the monkfish for our friend at the table as it was served open grilled with a rather daunting appearance! I had a taste and it also was really wonderful. At the end, he even brought us each a complimentary sweet and rich liqueur. I've read reviews that say this place is inexpensive. They must have been in the tapas bar rather than the restaurant, because it was definitely NOT an inexpensive meal for us. With a glass of wine to start and two coffees to finish, the bill came to well over 90 euros. But I never mind paying up when a restaurant serves me great food and gives me outstanding service!

They brought us a small plate of paella as an appetiser which was nice while we waited for our food. The food came out in drips and drabs which I know how it usually works with tapas but some dishes arrived a good 20-30 mins after the first ones. The albondigas weren't brilliant so I wouldn't suggest ordering that, and the service wasn't brilliant. We must have spent about 2 hours in that restaurant and half an hour of that was asking for the bill! The restaurant is quiet and peaceful though which was nice after spending a morning fighting our way through the El Rastro flea market.

title_review: A gem in the heart of La Latina
review_preview: Was looking for a place a notch above the street fare of La Latina. Found it here. A bit more expensive than the average for the area but a worthwhile oasis. Speak English, are friendly, the service is great as is the food, You are...
review_full: Was looking for a place a notch above the street fare of La Latina. Found it here. A bit more expensive than the average for the area but a worthwhile oasis. Speak English, are friendly, the service is great as is the food, You are greeted with many complimentary delicacies while choosing your dining options from an ambitious menu and wine list. The place is busy- testament to its goodness- but they handle the flow well. Both my wife and I had fish- she the hake, me the cod with prawns. Both were mouth-watering delicious. The preceding crab soup was excellent. Without dessert, the tab came to about 70 euros, but it was worth every penny of it. Would go back if in the area or as a special side trip. About 6 minutes from La Latina metro stop..

However, when I went they didn't have anymore.  The prices are quite reasonable. The place is a bit small so sometimes it may be difficult to find a table. They only have high tables and chairs.  It is a nice place to stop and eat some "Raciones" and then continue having some more things in other places of the area.

title_review: Awesome, affordable Spanish food and drinks
review_preview: We heard about this place by watching videos on YouTube (thanks to The Spain Guy) and we were so glad we went. After visiting the unimpressive Mercado next door, we were very hungry (and thirsty). We had heard that they have the best Spanish Toritilla,...
review_full: We heard about this place by watching videos on YouTube (thanks to The Spain Guy) and we were so glad we went. After visiting the unimpressive Mercado next door, we were very hungry (and thirsty). We had heard that they have the best Spanish Toritilla, so of course we ordered it, along with the Albondigas (meatballs), beer, and vermouth. I had many tortillas in Spain, but this one was the best by far. The meatballs were also great, especially with the free bread that they served us. Our entire bill was only 14 Euros, for the two dishes and four drinks! The owners are super nice and humble. They have operated this business together for 50 years! I wish I had a bigger stomach because I wanted to try more of their food. Oh well, I guess I'll just have to go back to Madrid someday to try the rest of their menu.

The waiter was so nice that my wife want him to serve us next time. Good humor.

title_review: The best tortilla espanola y wonderful owners

review_full: This is small family run bar that is right across from the San Miguel Market. As soon as you are about to enter San Miguel turn around and you will find this place. This place has the best tortilla espanola you can imagine (and we tried more than a dozen of them and this was hands down the best). The owners are super friendly and engaging, even inviting our teenage kids into the kitchen to learn how to cook. The prices are also much lower than you will find right across at the touristy San Miguel Market. We recommend this place wholeheartedly.

review_preview: Tapas Tapas Tapas - unavioidable in Madrid. And most often a fun way to eat your way thru Spain. But if you grow a bit tired of this country's contribution to the culinary scene, then come to Antonita's on Cava Baja street in the Latin...
review_full: Tapas Tapas Tapas - unavioidable in Madrid. And most often a fun way to eat your way thru Spain. But if you grow a bit tired of this country's contribution to the culinary scene, then come to Antonita's on Cava Baja street in the Latin area (La Latina) for a 'Tapas Gone Modern' experience.  Friendly and attentive staff and nice atmosphere adds to the many tasty reinvented Tapas choices.  A standout is the 'Soap' dessert. A disc of white chocolate mousse (with lavender?) surrounded by citrus bubbles (foam). An inventive and light way to end the meal.

review_preview: We have been in Spain for a week and so far this is my favorite tapas restaurant.  It is tucked into El Latino and can be easily missed.  We happened upon it after being unable to be seated in several other sites frequented by a...
review_full: We have been in Spain for a week and so far this is my favorite tapas restaurant. It is tucked into El Latino and can be easily missed. We happened upon it after being unable to be seated in several other sites frequented by a younger crowd. This was a great find. The staff spoke limited English but their experience and limited menu made the night seamless. During our dinner there only 5 seatings. Our table of 8, another table of 8, two tables of 4 and a table of 2. Each table was provided incredible service. The patrons were as varied as a United Nations Conference. I was so impressed by the staff’s ability to serve persons of such diverse backgrounds with such ease and joy.  Do not miss choosing a Spanish wine for the start of your meal. The selections are small but pair well with the meal and are very nicely priced. The staff was ready to help with the selection. They also have sangria that looked marvelous but we were drawn to the wine selection.  Our group combines a variety of dietary demands. We have vegetarians, flexitarians, pescatarians and omnivores. This restaurant’s menu allowed us to satisfy all. We selected a wide range of options and even then we wanted more.  Chistorra—could not get enough;  Manchego Cheese—nicely aged, cut thin, topped with walnut halves and blackberry jam; Broken Eggs with Potatoes—a flavor and texture that calls for seconds, thirds and fourths and is still on your mind in the morning;  Roe Deer Sirloin—flavors and tender texture that is unique and compelling;  Veal Meatballs—a rich taste treat that moves ground meat to a higher plain;  Roasted Red Pepper Salad—a salad that was gone in an instant;  Spanish Potato Salad—unique and profound flavors that still linger in my memory (so different and a must experience dish);  Red Pepper with Cod Fish—a flavor that even our fish avoiders enjoyed;  Cup of Casserole of the Day was Lentil Soup—a rich and hearty soup that could have been a meal in itself.  I would go back to try several other options that did not fit on our table.  Then the dessert tray was delivered. The selections were many. It was the first time we saw the tray and simply replied “Yes”. We have one of everything. Each one was different, luscious and a taste treat to end the evening.  Do not miss this intimate, small and rich place to share with your friends and family. This is a Spanish tapas prepared with care and much different than we have heretofore shared.

review_preview: We had been given a recommendation for this restaurant but were very disappointed. We arrived at 8:00pm, our reservation time. While we understand this is early based on typical Spanish times, the restaurant was in disarray. The tables were not set and, when our table...
review_full: We had been given a recommendation for this restaurant but were very disappointed. We arrived at 8:00pm, our reservation time. While we understand this is early based on typical Spanish times, the restaurant was in disarray. The tables were not set and, when our table was finally set, the tablecloth was still wet as if just pulled from the washing machine.  We then proceeded to order wine, water, and several courses. The wine was quickly delivered but the water required several inquiries.  The first course delivered was Tigre croquettes with a bland sauce. The croquettes were quite flavorless and the sauce did little to help.  Following almost immediately were the two vegetable courses, marinated heirloom tomatoes and grilled seasonal vegetables. Both were very good but were almost force fed in the apparent rush for the restaurant to be rid of us non-Spanish speaking interlopers.  Next we had the oxtail spring rolls, again based on a recommendation. And again delivered before we had enjoyed the previous course. These were rather nondescript stewed beef, wrapped in won-ton wrappers, and then served with two bland sauces that added nothing.  At this point, we requested that the pace be slowed since each course had been delivered with a Francoesque machine gun efficiency. We ordered an additional bottle of wine in the vain hope of slowing the onslaught.  Instead the Iberian Pork "secreto" (their quotes) with guacamole was forced onto our already crowded table despite our requests to slow the pace.  Finally since we had apparently crossed some Euro threshold, we were allowed to finish our (though now cold) meal in peace.  When asked about desert. We opted for the "soap" again based on a recommendation. The dish consisted of a lemon foam (hence the soap) with a central cake of lavender infused ice cream. Quite tasty but not worth the mediocrity of the food or the forced march pace by the kitchen and wait staff. The pricing was fair but overall not a good experience. We will not return given the richness of restaurants in Madrid that respect both the cuisine and the customer.

title_review: Classic Spain, Old School quality- the way it should be done.
review_preview: I wanted to try this restaurant after Anthony Bourdain reviewed it.  I'm happy we found it. Excellence. As an American who has traveled all over Spain for 35 years, I love this place. This food is prepared from scratch. We enjoyed the chorizo and jamón...
review_full: I wanted to try this restaurant after Anthony Bourdain reviewed it. I'm happy we found it. Excellence. As an American who has traveled all over Spain for 35 years, I love this place. This food is prepared from scratch. We enjoyed the chorizo and jamón iberico with the Manchego cheese to begin with. We also had some tortilla de patatas- which is a dish we make when we are back in the states. And the decor and history is a plus. I'll be back for certain. I hope it never goes away.  The service was excellent- professionals. And yes, in Spain, the Spanish speak ....drum roll....Spanish. If you expect English, perhaps stay near the tourist traps like the Plaza Mayor, McDonalds or KFC. The Spanish dining culture is different- they tend to eat later. I think the prices are moderate for a big city. Ive paid more in Chicago for corporate food.  Thanks Casa Salvador for doing it the right way. Thatnkas for a great experience.

review_preview: We were recommended to eat here by a local. They weren't wrong.5 of us dined, with dessert, wine and a sloe based drink at the end of the meal for under 40 euros each. That's great for a "city centre" location.We were brought...
review_full: We were recommended to eat here by a local.  They weren't wrong. 5 of us dined, with dessert, wine and a sloe based drink at the end of the meal for under 40 euros each. That's great for a "city centre" location. We were brought olives and pickled chillies as a pre meal nibble. I think I ate 6 chillies! Then some fried fish arrived. This was fantastic. We had a mix of starters, I had the chorizo, others had salads ans specialities. For main I went for the pollo al ajillo. This was delicious, but it is a jointed chicken, so be careful when you bite in, there's bones and everything. I went for the chocolate mousse for dessert, which was rich and thick. That was it, I was then full! The decor is very bullfight oriented, with photos and portraits, old and new. I'd heartily recommend this restaurant.

title_review: Busy bustling bar with great service
review_preview: We visited this bar on several occasions after pitching up there on our first night and  been served an enormous raba de toro (oxtail) which hit the spot, accompanied by a few beers. The next night , despite, a heaving crowd at the bar we...
review_full: We visited this bar on several occasions after pitching up there on our first night and been served an enormous raba de toro (oxtail) which hit the spot, accompanied by a few beers. The next night , despite, a heaving crowd at the bar we were spotted and immediately served by a very jokey and efficient barmaid, wine and beers all accompanied by small tapas, not the best but very palatable.Every succeeding night not only were we spotted, but the head barman automatically remembered our order, truly remarkable given the constant swell of people and claims on his attention.The decor is faded fin de siecle with added grunge which gives it an attractive atmosphere,and it is great for observing the Madrid social scene. The food is so so but I reckon this is down to the constant stream of orders putting pressure on a very small kitchen. But overall a very good experience will definitely return on next visit..

title_review: A wonderful journey into the past
review_preview: Casa Salvador is a classic! You enter a beautyfully decorated place that hasn´t changed since the 40ies. Everything is 100% old-schol Madrid. The braised oxtail is fantastic, so is the jamón, the meatballs etc. Plain and simple as it should be. The wines are also...
review_full: Casa Salvador is a classic! You enter a beautyfully decorated place that hasn´t changed since the 40ies. Everything is 100% old-schol Madrid. The braised oxtail is fantastic, so is the jamón, the meatballs etc. Plain and simple as it should be. The wines are also perfect for the food. For me, a trip to Madrid without a dinner at CS would not be complete. And by the way: if you don´t like bullfighting (there are hundereds of historical photos and posters on the walls), at least respect it... I really love this restaurant!

title_review: Great cheap eats and fun staff
review_preview: Fast service, incredibly efficient and friendly!We had el plato del dia, a roasted capon with cola glaze with fries and salad, enough to feed 2, for 8 Euros, a bottle of nice local red for 11E and a few tapas, 3-4E each. The food...
review_full: Fast service, incredibly efficient and friendly! We had el plato del dia, a roasted capon with cola glaze with fries and salad, enough to feed 2, for 8 Euros, a bottle of nice local red for 11E and a few tapas, 3-4E each. The food itself was simple, not extraordinary, but the dining experience was excellent and the staff are really great. With our first drinks we were brought a plate of braised ribs...just like that, for free! After three hours of leisurely eating in the fun, bright tavern, we asked for our bill, and though they were happy to oblige, they insisted we stay for a glass of sangria, on the house! (which turned out to be a PINT, not a glass, and excellent!) Will definitely go back, great value.

title_review: My only disappointment while traveling in Spain
review_preview: We happened to pass by the Esteban restaurant today and decided to have a few tapas for lunch as we normally do.  My order was "spanish sausage with bread". What I actually got was a single tiny slice of sausage a couple of millimeters thick......
review_full: We happened to pass by the Esteban restaurant today and decided to have a few tapas for lunch as we normally do. My order was "spanish sausage with bread". What I actually got was a single tiny slice of sausage a couple of millimeters thick... No shortage of breadcrumbs though... Price: nearly €6. Worst thing I tried in two weeks in Spain. The attitude of the staff was obviously unfriendly, so I decided not to order more tapas. A real nasty surprice came at the end - they've added to the bill extra €2 "for bread" which I didn't order. They refused to take it from the bill on my request stating that they always add bread charge "per table". That again, was the only experience of this kind during the trip - in all the other places things like bread, oil for salad etc have never been billed separately. Honestly, with such a poor level of service these guys don't deserve to be in business for long, and the beautiful city of Madrid would be better without them.  Avoid going there - from my experience ANY other restaurant is a better option.

title_review: HIgher end amongst the calle Cava Baja touristy places
review_preview: My girlfriend and I went here on our first night in Madrid. It was fairly early by Spain standards for dinner. We and another couple were seated in the front. Ordered our drinks and perused the menu. The server brought us olives while we sipped...
review_full: My girlfriend and I went here on our first night in Madrid. It was fairly early by Spain standards for dinner. We and another couple were seated in the front. Ordered our drinks and perused the menu. The server brought us olives while we sipped out drinks. I had a beer and my girlfriend had a glass of Rioja. We ordered the Rabo de toro estofado from the tapas menu. We were surprised by how large the portion was and glad. The stew was excellent. The service was excellent as well. Our server brought over bread before our dish came out, we declined since we'd planned on trying other tapas bars on the street and didn't want to fill up on bread. The waiter took the bread back and let us know that they don't charge for the bread. Most restaurants in Spain charge for the bread, so it was nice that they aren't one of those places.

title_review: Stew of the day to die for
review_preview: We stopped in for tapas around 3pm, there was a small party in the restaurant but we sat in the bar which suited us better.  We fancied something a bit different and opted for 'stew of the day' and veal meatballs with a couple of...
review_full: We stopped in for tapas around 3pm, there was a small party in the restaurant but we sat in the bar which suited us better. We fancied something a bit different and opted for 'stew of the day' and veal meatballs with a couple of ice cold beers in chilled glasses, which we were thankful for as it was really hot outside. We had no idea what was in the stew and didn't ask as we just went with it. Needless to say it was delicious, ham, onions and white beans in an amazing sauce. The meatballs were the same. When we had finished the owner bought us a plate of tuna potato salad for free which we wolfed down. The owner spoke little English which made the whole experience much more fun. Couldn't fault it at all. For two tapas and 4 beers it was about €22

Partner of the restaurant showed us to part of his hotel and showed us to this really pretty see-through basement he had in the restaurant. review_full: This is one of the best restaurants in madrid. The atmosphere is great, packed with people and with incredible architecture features - in one of the rooms you're sat on top of the ruins of old madrid.  Fantastic staff, super polite and the chef even came and chat with us explaining the background of one of the desserts - la antoñita soap- an amazing white chocolate and lavender parfait with lime foam. We ordered about 6 tapas- croquetas, prawn fritters, Russian salad with caviar, pork chops with pineapple, squid and some greens and everything was cooked to perfection and had a great balance between haute cuisine and rustic Latina vibes. A great experience and I highly recommend it.

review_preview: We entered this restaurant in "old" Madrid because we were in the area, and the exhibit in the window (partridges) looked good. The waiters greeted us affably and SINCERELY -- with joking formality ( we are Spanish speakers...). The exhibit at the bar was a...
review_full: We entered this restaurant in "old" Madrid because we were in the area, and the exhibit in the window (partridges) looked good. The waiters greeted us affably and SINCERELY -- with joking formality ( we are Spanish speakers...). The exhibit at the bar was a wonderful-looking lechona asada -- roast baby pig -- which I ordered, and it was even better than it looked: THE BEST lechona I've ever had! My husband had ox-tail, which he claimed was as good as at home; dodn't remember what the rest of the group ordered. All in all, we had a wonderful time, eating, drinking a good Rivera del Duero, and chatting with the waiters -- so give this traditional looking restaurant a try!

review_preview: I have dined in this restaurant before and would have agreed with the positive reviews here...before tonight. Where to start? The appetizer, grilled vegetables, was overdone and barely passable. The waiter snatched my bread away (that I had barely touched) after the appetizer without asking...
review_full: I have dined in this restaurant before and would have agreed with the positive reviews here...before tonight. Where to start? The appetizer, grilled vegetables, was overdone and barely passable. The waiter snatched my bread away (that I had barely touched) after the appetizer without asking and before I could say "Don't". I swallowed all this in anticipation of the highlight of the dinner - cochinillo asado (roasted suckling pig) which is supposedly one of their specialties. Well... this was the big disappointment of the night: it was a small, thin piece of a rib cage that was way overcooked. The skin that should be crispy was totally burned, a third of it was black and I had to cut it out and leave it on the plate. I have eaten cochinillo quite a few times in Spain and this was without any qualification the worst. The good ambience could not make up for the taste of soot in my mouth. I am willing to assume it was all due to the fact it was Saturday night and they were busy, but am not willing to test this assumption by going there again. So will stay away.

title_review: Outstanding food, service, atmosphere and service
review_preview: We ate an early lunch at Esteban Restaurant - and were much relieved to discover that they were happy to serve before the typical Spanish 2:00 lunch hour. We were welcomed although we were at first the only diners. Our steaks w/ frites, and the...
review_full: We ate an early lunch at Esteban Restaurant - and were much relieved to discover that they were happy to serve before the typical Spanish 2:00 lunch hour. We were welcomed although we were at first the only diners. Our steaks w/ frites, and the roast chicken prepared in an egg and almond sauce with rice were outstanding. Breads were artfully set out at the table, and were bakery fresh. We were given complimentary portions of a beef soup, and olives with gerkins. The Sangria was excellent and freshly prepared at the bar. Service was so hospitable and friendly. We also were treated to a Jerez brandy after dinner. Staff tried to talk whatever English they could, as we tried to communicate in our mix of French, Italian and possibly Spanish! Menus were in "Inglese por favore", by request.The pictures of celebrity athlete diners shown to our young adult son was a special treat.

review_preview: Madrid – Dinner at Restaurante Esteban on Cava Baja – Chosen by whim and perhaps a dash of instinct on the crowded, crazy boulevard of tapas, this was a warm, friendly, delicious evening. We stayed in the bar area up front, but watched many folks...
review_full: Madrid – Dinner at Restaurante Esteban on Cava Baja – Chosen by whim and perhaps a dash of instinct on the crowded, crazy boulevard of tapas, this was a warm, friendly, delicious evening. We stayed in the bar area up front, but watched many folks head for the dining room. Traditional tapas galore: pimientos rojos, those amazing light green olives, jamon, albondigas, chorizo, morcilla (blood sausage), and substantial servings of slices of suckling pig and a leg of roast baby lamb my wife saw, smiled, and pointed at while exploring the room. The house Rioja flowed and it was a wonderful meal. Before we could leave, one of the very friendly waiters insisted we wait so he could go to the freezer, pull out a mysterious bottle, and pour us short glasses of a terrific digestif, perhaps a Pacharán? We would return.

We would normally raise any problems with the management at the time of eating and tend not to post on on-line negative reviews but [and this is our problem, not the restaurant's] our poor Spanish did not make this a realistic possibility. With a very decent and, we thought, fairly-priced bottle of Rioja [25 Euro] our bill came to 99 Euro. We declined desserts and coffee...

review_preview: We went here for lunch and it wasn't the best of places to experience. We were sat in the bar area not the main restaurant section which had space (Only 2 of us). The waiter wasn't very friendly and literally huffed and rolled his eyes...
review_full: We went here for lunch and it wasn't the best of places to experience. We were sat in the bar area not the main restaurant section which had space (Only 2 of us). The waiter wasn't very friendly and literally huffed and rolled his eyes at our polite attempts to speak Spanish. Our menus were snatched from us, complimentary bread thrown on the table and then also chicken wings also thrown down (very nice I must add though!). The staff seemed to just shout at each other... a lot and then our food came - hubby ordered paella which came immediately and I had a tomatoe & egg dish which came out a little while after. Once finished our plates were snatched away, and we were ignored as staff flew past us almost spilling drinks and food on us at one point, with no apology!  Very disappointed as we are quite well travelled and I do not think we are the typical moaning type with too high standards, quite the opposite! So it's a shame to leave a bad review but may make the owner and staff think a little about behaviour. Certainly reasonably priced I'll give it that, setting is lovely in terms of interier but much to be said about the staff and service.

title_review: Best Value for money in Madrid
review_preview: Don't expect cordon bleu, the chalked menu boards outside make the place look very similar to many of the other bars in the area, However do expect great food obliging happy staff and a bill that is a pleasure to pay.  The "Menu del Dia"...
review_full: Don't expect cordon bleu, the chalked menu boards outside make the place look very similar to many of the other bars in the area, However do expect great food obliging happy staff and a bill that is a pleasure to pay. The "Menu del Dia" offered a good selection with plenty of temptation. We had a "Cogollo" salad with smoked salmon - huge, tasty and well garnished. I Ordered a "Paella Marinera" which we were eventually informed was "all finished" profuse apologies were offered and I reselected a dish of prawns and antillas which was served in a sizzling, bubbling dish of oil with garlic. Wonderful. The main courses were equally special, A large plate of calamares served with a comprehensive salad garnish, and an entrecôte steak with fries plenty of chewing but delicious. We passed on the "postre" but coffee was offered as an alternative. Additionally to the menu drinks included we ordered a bottle of wine which came in at the, lowest price that I have paid in the last 8 or 9 years.

title_review: Nice little place, unfussy but good
review_preview: Tripadvisor has revolutionised the market, with over 3,000 places to eat on Madrid, how does a short visit punter decide where to get some decent value for money fodder - well, this place was well rated, so, booking made (glad we did, got very busy)...
review_full: Tripadvisor has revolutionised the market, with over 3,000 places to eat on Madrid, how does a short visit punter decide where to get some decent value for money fodder - well, this place was well rated, so, booking made (glad we did, got very busy) Saturday dinner it was. We had a table on the glass floor over the exposed wall of the original city, nice to see it was too. A limited menu always appeals to me, less likely to be pre-packed mass market rubbish - and not disappointed at all. There is a 2 man 'hot pass' in the restaurant and more cooking and preparing out the back, but good to see them preparing some dishes in front of you. The tapas selection is not massive, but the cod tempura and shrimp fritters were great, in fact, we ordered on advice 4 dishes and it was fine for 2 of us. Decent bottle of red for good measure and all in, a lovely evening in this great eating district of Madrid

review_preview: First of all, my husband and I were looking for a different restaurant from the one we had previously chosen.We had no idea where to go. Then, when we passed by Esteban something special about its looks made us get inside. It did seem...
review_full: First of all, my husband and I were looking for a different restaurant from the one we had previously chosen. We had no idea where to go. Then, when we passed by Esteban something special about its looks made us get inside. It did seem quite pleasant - and it really was. We were made extremely welcome by the owner, a typical Spaniard man. His daughter (?), who was working as hostess, was incredibly polite. It's Esteban is a small restaurant with a few tables, a burgundy velvet curtain separating the bar from the dining room. The walls are full of historical and old pictures transporting us to the atmosphere of an old tavern. Nevertheless, this historical perspective does not make us forget the XXI century because at the same time we were invited to enjoy all the comfort that modernity offers. The food is absolutely delicious. Considering our 10-day trip between Madrid and Northern Portugal, Esteban was undoubtedly the best restaurant in my opinion. My dish was superb: 'Bonito del Norte con tomate' (Atlantic bonito fish with the best tomato sause that I ever have tasted). As a typical Brazilian I love white rice. Therefore I asked if they could change my order by serving the fish with white rice, which they gently did. My husband also loved his choice, 'Boquerones en vinagre o en escabeche' (fried European anchovies in vinegar) The wine list is very complete. Simply fabulous - an invitation to taste Spain at its best!

title_review: Took a chance and it paid off!
review_preview: Last day of a nine week tour of Italy and Spain we decided to spend the first part of the day at the El Rastro flea market in Madrid before walking around the La Latina area and choosing a place for lunch at random. We...
review_full: Last day of a nine week tour of Italy and Spain we decided to spend the first part of the day at the El Rastro flea market in Madrid before walking around the La Latina area and choosing a place for lunch at random. We wanted it to be not overtly touristy but with restaurant facilities so we could enjoy a leisurely Sunday lunch. This was always going to be a risky business as most places that are any good are generally fully booked for Sunday lunch. And so after a couple of knock backs from fully booked restaurants we found the last table for two at Esteban which was lucky as just after we were seated the place filled up as all the reserved tables became occupied. We had arrived at 2.30 pm and the locals turned up in force at 3.00 pm. From beginning to end we had an excellent experience, with the service being very friendly and relaxed with a menu in English being provided immediately and an English speaking waiter being assigned to watch over us. I would describe the food as very homely and the specialities of the house had obviously served this establishment very well for many years. The food whilst giving the appearance of being very simple was in fact well honed and based on good quality ingredients. We shared an entree of white asparagus tips and a main course each of bull's tail stew and home made meatballs. Perfect food that was very tasty but surprisingly light. Many tables seemed to be having the roast piglet or slow roasted lamb, both of which looked very nice. Wine choices were good with a small bottle of Cava for my wife and a good quality half bottle of red for myself. One desert, a digestive and two coffees later we ended up with a bill of €100 including a good tip. We loved the experience of being the only tourists in the house but included in a way that we too felt part of the whole Sunday family lunch enjoyed by the local Madridians that surrounded us. A great experience and based on our lovely afternoon we would recommend that you consider a visit to Esteban whilst in Madrid.

review_preview: Living in Madrid for around 3 months, I've never been treated so bad in a restaurant. Though I spoke spanish with the waiters, I was speaking english with my friend.At the beggining the waiters were friendly and helpful, but then they started to treat...
review_full: Living in Madrid for around 3 months, I've never been treated so bad in a restaurant. Though I spoke spanish with the waiters, I was speaking english with my friend. At the beggining the waiters were friendly and helpful, but then they started to treat us different from the spanish customers. We asked for a beer and they served us a low quality beer different from all the other tables, the portions were really poor and expensive. The food was cold. Attention: VAT it's not included on the price you see on the menu! this is not normal in spain, and though on the menu it says "8% VAT not included"(tiny tiny letters) they will charge you 10%. When I asked about this, the waiter told me they didn't want to change the menus all the time. This VAT increase in spain was made more than 1 year ago. I'm not going back there.

review_preview: This restaurant was described in a TA review as very modern, but I would describe it as an updated version of Spanish traditional food and atmosphere that still remains true to its roots. You'll find the typical croquettes, cod and charcuterie here, but those dishes...
review_full: This restaurant was described in a TA review as very modern, but I would describe it as an updated version of Spanish traditional food and atmosphere that still remains true to its roots. You'll find the typical croquettes, cod and charcuterie here, but those dishes are given a more interesting twist while also being paired with dishes that have more contemporary culinary influences (superb salmon tartar, for example). They have an excellent selection of wines and  desserts. I didn't find the 'foam' dessert to be as amazing as other reviews suggested, but it was interesting and still worth trying. The floor of part of the restaurant is made of glass so you can see the archeological excavations below--which adds just another layer of interest to this excellent restaurant. Located in the trendy Cava Baja for those in need of Pre or post-dinner bar hopping. Highly recommended.

title_review: Excellent fresh seafood, very generous portions.
review_preview: Recommened for excellent seafood at very reasonable price, and fast service, we were a little concerned at how busy it was at 1st, we got seated, and as in many restaurants in Spain the waitor simply handed the menu to my wife and I and...
review_full: Recommened for excellent seafood at very reasonable price, and fast service, we were a little concerned at how busy it was at 1st, we got seated, and as in many restaurants in Spain the waitor simply handed the menu to my wife and I and then left, without even taking a drink order, I can never understand this in Spain. Ee waited quite a while before he returned and actually considered leaving, as we a had babysitter and our alone togethet time is very rare these days. But all was soon to be forgiven, as after he came and took our order, the food seemed to arrive in minutes, it was absolutely delicious and definately the freshest seafood I have had in a city so far from the coast. We shared the seafood platter for two people and really struggled to eat it all. Highly recommended don't be put off by how busy it is, or the initial wait, because it is well worth it, and it is busy for a very good reason!!

review_preview: Looking for a nicer dinner one night on a recent family trip to Madrid, I noticed Casa Gallega. I expected an excellent seafood-based meal, and that is what we got. The appetizers were wonderful: Galician cod empanadas and cod croquettes. The empanadas differ from standard...
review_full: Looking for a nicer dinner one night on a recent family trip to Madrid, I noticed Casa Gallega. I expected an excellent seafood-based meal, and that is what we got. The appetizers were wonderful: Galician cod empanadas and cod croquettes. The empanadas differ from standard Spanish ones: they are more like a small cake, rectangular with a thick crust and a slightly sweet stuffing heavy on onions and raisins, offsetting the fish. The croquettes were crispy, perfectly fried, and had a creamy filling with only a hint of cod flavor. Many courses were wonderful too, including beautiful baked fish. Make a reservation, plan to stay a while, and enjoy a superb meal from one of Spain's regional cuisines.

review_full: We sought out Casa Salvador based on Trip Advisor reviews, and had our hotel book for 9 p.m. on a Friday (which is when the restaurant opens). It is located north of Gran Via on a corner in a colorful neighborhood (local fabric and hardware stores along with "XXX" bars). Like other reviewers, we were the only patrons at 9 p.m. when seated in a room on the main floor, but we watched a steady stream of regular patrons climb to the upstairs dining area. The restaurant is filled with old bullfighting photographs, programs, posters and paintings. The older man who waited on us, presumable the owner, could not have been more helpful. He gave us a table in a cozy side room that never became overheated, even after more patrons joined us. He gave us menus in Spanish and English then brought the album of photos to explain many of the dishes. He also brought a small serving dish of green olives that tasted of lemon or a light vinegar, and french rolls. We ordered a mixed vegetable plate (panache de verduras) which was served to both of us on individual plates and was flavorful (spinach, cauliflower, mushrooms, carrots) all evenly cooked and seasoned. I then had the lenguado plancha, described as grilled salmon but I think it was sole, the whole fish without the head, grilled to perfection with soft moist flesh. I boned it myself, but you might ask him to do it. It was served simply with a large wedge of lemon and another of tomato and a small yellow potato. My dining mate ordered rabo restofado, oxtail roasted and served with sauce, peas, carrots, and potato. He found it a bit fatty but enjoyed it. We ordered the house vino tinto (Rioja Bordon), something we drink at home. Chocolate ice cream (helado chocolato) was very good but not gelato. Our entire meal with cover and a bottle of water and coffee was 63 euros, served timely and with attentive but not hovering service. By 10 p.m. the place was nearly full. This is a great neighborhood restaurant with a large enough menu to satisfy, especially after a long flight.

We are not very big eaters, so we just wanted to order a paella, a portion of tortilla, and then by suggestion of the waiter, we ate a tapa of pork (I don't remember the name, but it was the first one of the menu section, with apricot jam).  Tortilla was huge for 3€! I could be full just with that. The eggs are not super cooked, but that's just the way I like tortilla, and I guess this is why some people say their tortilla is weird.... Then the pork tapa was super delicious, and much bigger than i expected, as I'm used to smaller tapas. Finally the paella was also good, although probably not the the best I've tasted. The thing I like about this place, is that they offer you a tapa when you order your drinks, and we had choricitos with patatas fritas. The waiters are also very joyful and funny, and the ambiance is really cool. Im definitely coming back in the future!

Everything was so so good. The Gazpacho was refreshing on a hot summer night, we've had Gazpacho in restaurants in the State, it doesn't compare. We've had fried squid many times before, in the PNW where there is fresh seafood. However, the squid in Casa Gallega is so much tastier (they keep everything in the squid, including the squid ink). The grilled seafood contained shrimp, crayfish, scallop, mussels, and razor clams, so fresh and tasty! We'd go back again for sure.

title_review: Felt a part of Spanish History
review_preview: Hidden away a stone's throw from the bustling Plaza Chueca we got a nice welcome to Casa Salvador, although it was a shame that the bar at the entrance was abandoned and the restaurant seemed a little under-staffed. However the initial disappointment fell away as...
review_full: Hidden away a stone's throw from the bustling Plaza Chueca we got a nice welcome to Casa Salvador, although it was a shame that the bar at the entrance was abandoned and the restaurant seemed a little under-staffed. However the initial disappointment fell away as we absorbed the atmosphere in this gem of a restaurant. The menu of mainly Spanish cuisine was varied and well-priced; the wine selection was very good and I would definitely recommend the Marques de Riscal 2010 which was a particularly crisp and fruity Rioja. The starters that were accompanied with olives and crusty bread were massive and absolutely delicious. And the mains did not disappoint either. Although there was not much space for dessert, these too are varied and well priced.  The walls of this restaurant are covered with bull-fighting paraphernalia and photographs and there are paintings of the restaurant interior as it was between 1941 when it opened and today which show how little it has changed over the years.

title_review: Delicious, traditional food and cozy, authentic atmosphere!
review_preview: Stepping through the door of Casa Salvador is like entering the authentic heart of a disappearing Spain. Every square inch of the wood-paneled wall is covered with paintings and black-and-white photographs. Most of it is bullfighting paraphernalia collected by the restaurant's founder, along with beautiful...
review_full: Stepping through the door of Casa Salvador is like entering the authentic heart of a disappearing Spain. Every square inch of the wood-paneled wall is covered with paintings and black-and-white photographs. Most of it is bullfighting paraphernalia collected by the restaurant's founder, along with beautiful shots of old Madrid and photos of celebrities who visited Casa Salvador in days gone by. (The biggest names I spotted were Ernest Hemingway and Ava Gardner.) The layout is cozy and familiar while the waiters' pristine, white jackets let you know you'll be taken care of. The overall effect is incredibly charming, particularly for those seeking authenticity and one-of-a-kind venues. And if that's not enough to convince you, there's always the food! "Merluza" (hake, a mild white fish) is one of the specialties of the house. I generally find hake so-so -- but this was like no hake I'd had before! Fluffy, flavorful, lightly breaded and golden brown: yum! I couldn't get enough of it. We also had shrimp in a garlic sauce (delicious!) and artichokes with ham, along with some traditional "embutidos" (cured meats). Everything was outstanding. Far from the slick, impersonal modernity of many new Madrid restaurants, Casa Salvador is a must-visit for those looking for a traditional Spanish experience of quality and warmth. I know I'll be back!

The restaurant has a Madrid 1920s feel, a haunt you might encounter in a Hemingway book. In fact, Papa Hemingway himself visited the restaurant back in the day. There´s even photo evidence that can be seen on the walls of the famous writer with restaurant´s founder. Casa Salvador provided spot on service and care for us all throughout the night, something that can be hard to find in Spain. It´s a place that really has a great ambience, delicious traditional food and friendly service. I would definitely return.

The first thing you notice is the bright lighting and then that the decor, furniture, pictures on the walls, crockery and even the waiters have probably not changed one bit in the last 50 years. Beware of the house red, a robust wine that left us feeling a little jaded the next morning. Nevertheless a pleasant experience.

review_preview: I have been dining in this restaurant since my first visit to Madrid in 1996. More recently due to my travels I am here at least once a month for the past 8 years. The decor is so incredibly homely with photos dating back over...
review_full: I have been dining in this restaurant since my first visit to Madrid in 1996. More recently due to my travels I am here at least once a month for the past 8 years. The decor is so incredibly homely with photos dating back over 50 years of bullfighters, famous faces, the staff and customers. The food is very typical spanish with a menu that has not changed much in the years I have been visiting. For that reason the food is prepared to the same excellent standard every visit with a sizeable menu to choose from. The owner/chef who unfortunately recently passed away, started as a dishwasher and moved up the ranks to eventually buy the restaurant over 30 odd years ago. His daughter has now taken over and, continued the tradition of offering great spanish food at great prices. The waiters all dress in traditional waiter uniforms from the 60's are friendly and helpfull in their suggestions to tourists of what to choose. The service is excellent, delivery of food is swift and the taste is authentic spanish. This is also a place where you do not feel embaressed to enter on your own, a mix of spanish, tourists and singe people can be found here every day and evening.

title_review: Traditional Spanish food, great prices & atmosphere
review_preview: If you're looking for Madrid and Spanish life in a nutshell, go to La Alhambra. The menu is all traditional Spanish cuisine (the fried goat cheese and blueberry sauce might be the best appetizer ever), and the staff is so hospitable and friendly. Nights are...
review_full: If you're looking for Madrid and Spanish life in a nutshell, go to La Alhambra. The menu is all traditional Spanish cuisine (the fried goat cheese and blueberry sauce might be the best appetizer ever), and the staff is so hospitable and friendly. Nights are always busy with locals and it's a hotspot for both young, old, and families. The prices are what makes it even better; two great entrees an app, and a nice bottle of wine is usually around 25 euro. Nothing like that where I'm from! If you're looking to experience Madrileno nightlife and food, but not looking to spend too much, La Alhambra is a must.
