title_review: Enjoyable Dining Experience in the Chueca District
review_preview: We ate here our third night in Madrid. Located in the Chueca district this is a fairly large restaurant at least compared to most places where we dined in Spain and is relatively easy to find since it is located at the intersection of two...
review_full: We ate here our third night in Madrid. Located in the Chueca district this is a fairly large restaurant at least compared to most places where we dined in Spain and is relatively easy to find since it is located at the intersection of two streets. We did not have reservations but arrived early by Madrid standards (around 9 PM) and were seated in the upstairs area. The room was filled with many vintage photos of matadors and bullfights which I initially assumed were there for us tourists. My understanding though is that the restaurant has been around since 1941 and many of the photos have been here since the 40’s and 50’s, reflecting the interests and passions of not only the owner but the many locals who apparently eat here. In some respects it was like eating in a museum. A waiter quickly came to our table and provided us menus in English-yay! I ordered the Mixed Salad to start and the Beef Steak with Fries as my entrée along with a bottle of Moritz, the popular Catalan beer, something I enjoyed frequently during our days in Spain. My partner had the Chicken Croquettes followed by the Shrimp Salad along with a large bottle of Solán de Cabras, the premium brand of mineral water in Spain. Our food and beverages arrived promptly. All items were very tasty and well prepared; portions for each item were enormous. Because the meal was so filling we decided to pass on dessert even though what I saw others enjoying looked very good. Our total bill came to 51 Euros, which considering the quality and quantity of food we had I thought was quite reasonable. By the time we left, the restaurant was fairly full. Overall I thought this was an enjoyable place to dine and would recommend it to others.

review_preview: We stumbled upon this place by accident because the restaurant originally recommended by our hostel was closed. We were there at 8, which is early by Spanish dinner standards, but we were still met warmly by an English-speaking waitress who served us tapas on the...
review_full: We stumbled upon this place by accident because the restaurant originally recommended by our hostel was closed. We were there at 8, which is early by Spanish dinner standards, but we were still met warmly by an English-speaking waitress who served us tapas on the house and confidently gave her recommendations on the menu. We ordered from the mains; the octopus, the steak, the red tuna, the oxtail stew and the paella (twice!) All good food and great value for money especially the paella (only 7 euro for a decently big helping). Definitely recommending this to everyone traveling to Madrid!

review_preview: We were hungry so we settled for tapas. The kitchen in this place starts serving dinner food after 8pm. The tapas were different from the usual chorizos and jamon. We had empanada bonito, which turned out to be tasty tuna in a crust. The rabo...
review_full: We were hungry so we settled for tapas. The kitchen in this place starts serving dinner food after 8pm. The tapas were different from the usual chorizos and jamon. We had empanada bonito, which turned out to be tasty tuna in a crust. The rabo de toro was not a stew but a crispy roll stuffed with the famous dish. For dessert, we followed the waiter's suggestion. It was like the French millefeull pastry but layered with lavender cream. The other dessert had a most unusual presentation . It looked like a baron soap complete with foam. It was actually a white chocolate concoction. This was given free since it arrived so late. We liked the food a lot but service was slow. But the waiters did seem to be charming and knew how to sell their food, encouraging us to try their desserts. We may go back there tonight for the dinner food.

review_preview: We made reservations on-line for dinner on the same day. We had an 8:00 pm reservation and were the first to be seated. Service was fantastic despite our limited (as in zero) Spanish. We had a bottle of cava, a small (gratis) appetizer of tortilla...

We had a bottle of cava, a small (gratis) appetizer of tortilla espanola, the "special" salad with avocadoes and mango, garlic prawns, and the grilled seafood for two. The last was a giant platter with every crustacean you can imagine and some that you can't. It was all fresh and delicious and was topped with a small complimentary pour of liquer and a taste of cake. My only complaint was the dreadful music that sounded like it came from an elevator in the 1990's. I wish we could have had a listen to someone's i-pod but other than that, it was a lovely, old-fashioned dinner with great service.

review_preview: I was there twice. First time was when I was starting a tour in Europe with a group of 7 people. I was looking for a restaurant by 10:00 p.m and everything was full. I stepped in and asked to a waiter if we can...
review_full: I was there twice. First time was when I was starting a tour in Europe with a group of 7 people. I was looking for a restaurant by 10:00 p.m and everything was full. I stepped in and asked to a waiter if we can get a table. He told me he can get one for our group within 15 minutes but offered us immediately an appetizer, we decided to wait and right after short couple minutes he lead us to our table. This waiter made the night. His name is Felipe, gave us recommendations that we follow. No regrets with that. Everything was delicious and Felipe was caring of us very well. Other surprise came with the check, it was just 90 euros for the entire group.  Second time I went there when we returned to Madrid at the end of our tour. We were there again to celebrate my son's 9th birthday and Felipe was again taking care of us. Food was really good again and they had the nice detail of celebrate my son's birthday bringing a dessert for him, dimming the lights, putting a hat with lights on my son's head and singing the happy birthday (spanish version). I will recommend for sure this place to anybody looking for having a nice dinner in a nice ambient.

title_review: Favourite Place to Eat in Madrid
review_preview: Wonderful find as we wandered down the street one night in search of a place for dinner!  My parents, husband and I all absolutely loved this place and were eager to return before leaving Madrid.  The food was fantastic and the service was unbeatable.  On...
review_full: Wonderful find as we wandered down the street one night in search of a place for dinner! My parents, husband and I all absolutely loved this place and were eager to return before leaving Madrid. The food was fantastic and the service was unbeatable. On our return visit the waiter remembered us and greeted us warmly...which means a lot when you are far from home.  All of the food was fabulous...Patatas Bravas, Caesar Salad, Grilled Vegetables, Steak, etc. Make sure you save room for dessert! I think we tried all of them and every single one was fantastic! We are back in Canada now and are still talking what a great experience this was. We will definitely be returning here on our next trip to Madrid!

title_review: Good food, service could be improved
review_preview: We were looking for a tapas place for the evening and decided to check out the menus of a couple of places located at Cava Baja. We chose La Antonita based on their tapas menu. We sat down and ordered some wine. When we got...
review_full: We were looking for a tapas place for the evening and decided to check out the menus of a couple of places located at Cava Baja. We chose La Antonita based on their tapas menu. We sat down and ordered some wine. When we got the menu (which I was gonna use just to point out to the waitress what I wanted) I was rather disappointed, many of the tapas choices presented on the list outside the restaurant, were not on the menu now. I probably wouldn't have minded, except that all the options that didn't include meat, seemed to have disappeared, leaving me with only one or two options. The waitress seemed to seance our disappointment and started giving me recommendations that were not from the tapas menu. I ended up with some grilled tuna, which was delicious I must admit. My boyfriend chose some fried potatoes with eggs and Spanish ham and then some ribs and he was very pleased with his choice as well. The waitress was very helpful while we were choosing our food, but after the food was delivered, they seemed to lose interest in us, it was almost impossible to get any waitresses attention to order some more wine or water not to mention asking for the check. When we finally got our check I was a bit surprised that we had been charged for bread we never asked for, but I guess this is rather normal in many restaurants in Madrid. Prices are a bit higher than the average in Madrid, but nothing too bad. As the food was very delicious and it was prepared in an open kitchen, I can recommend this place for a nice dinner in Madrid.

Dessert was probably the best thing. Waiter did ask if all was ok and when I tried to mention about my fish he couldn't understand me ?? After seeing more of the great reviews this restaurant has got I think we must have gone on the Chef's night off.

title_review: Strongly recommended by our hotel, and rightly so.
review_preview: May seem strange to look for a great seafood restaurant in Madrid, many visitors still want meat or Paella. However, if you crave excellent seafood, look no further. From a shared grilled Octopus to our heavenly deserts a total meal was served impeccably.I see...
review_full: May seem strange to look for a great seafood restaurant in Madrid, many visitors still want meat or Paella. However, if you crave excellent seafood, look no further. From a shared grilled Octopus to our heavenly deserts a total meal was served impeccably. I see some comments about the Hake, which I chose, this was a wonderful surprise as it has been many many years since I enjoyed this fish. Cooked just right and my wife ate the Monkfish plus trimmings with great joy. A fine bottle of not overly expensive wine which the owner recommended was just what we needed. Deserts to die for, try the blueberry cheesecake it will melt in your mouth, so light, crepes for my wife. Round the meal off with a complimentary glass of a cross between Limoncello and Grappa superb. Cannot say enough good things about this restaurant, kudos all around.

review_preview: I'll keep it brief.Food:Outstanding. I had the Iberian pork resting on a mound of guacamole and I can safely say it was the best guacamole I have ever tasted in my life. My friend had the sea bream, one of the best she's...
review_full: I'll keep it brief. Food: Outstanding. I had the Iberian pork resting on a mound of guacamole and I can safely say it was the best guacamole I have ever tasted in my life. My friend had the sea bream, one of the best she's ever had. For starters we had the Chorizo which was tasty but do get bread with it (we didn't want any) and the fried potatoes which were awesome. This plus some drinks came to 55 euros which was very good. Trust me in London for the same quality of food we'd pay that each. Drinks wise do get the sangria upon arrival as it is very nice. Service:  By far the best service I have witnessed. The staff were very accommodating to some requests I made (Birthday ones, not snooty posh demands). They were friendly, chatty, easy going and were very good with their recommendations. The restaurant itself is very rustic and romantic looking, with a nice glass floor to see the restaurant resting over an old pit. Can not recommend this place enough 10 out of 10 Oh and we also had the privilege of meeting Pablo, some american bird's boyfriend, whom she only introduced about 20 times.

It's Spain so it's not like food is expensive to begin with anyway.  We ordered appetizers, entrees, drinks, dessert, and coffee and it came to about 40€ pp. Stateside that much food might cost $100 and I'd still think it was worth it.  Everything was delicious, but stick to the recommended items if you can't decide. Our personal favorites were the ox tail rolls and the "soap" for dessert (lavender, white chocolate, and a bit of lemon).  This is a must.

title_review: Modern Spanish Tapas in a historical spot!
review_preview: We arrived early (8:40 p.m. Is considered early!) and instead of being seated, was given a tour of the restaurant including the 12th century walls that are beneath the restaurant with glass floors, and then seated in the bar to have a cocktail before dinner....
review_full: We arrived early (8:40 p.m. Is considered early!) and instead of being seated, was given a tour of the restaurant including the 12th century walls that are beneath the restaurant with glass floors, and then seated in the bar to have a cocktail before dinner. We were with our family of four and met up with friends from back home who were on their second last day of their Spain trip. After looking over the menu we decided to let the fantastic waitress choose what dishes we should have and every single dish that came out was unbelievable. The finale being the soap dessert, was a great finish to a great night with a bottle of red and white wines to compliment the various dishes. Cannot recommend this restaurant enough, great service, fantastic food and memories to last a lifetime.

title_review: Go early for menu del dia
review_preview: We dropped by this taberna at 4.20 pm after a visit to the museum.  This was probably late for lunch even by Spanish standards but they were still offering the 3-course menu del dia at 13 euros.  The first server could not speak English but...
review_full: We dropped by this taberna at 4.20 pm after a visit to the museum. This was probably late for lunch even by Spanish standards but they were still offering the 3-course menu del dia at 13 euros. The first server could not speak English but another helpful staff came and explained the menu to us. My appetizer turned out to be prawns cooked in garlic with gulas (mock eel) which I didn't quite enjoy as I thought it would only be prawns. My main course of entrecot de lomo (steak) came with a large helping of french fries. The steak was a cheap cut and was thin and uneven in places so it was quite difficult to cook it evenly. My husband fared better with his choice. His appetizer of seafood paella was moist and delicious with a fair amount of mussels and prawns. He also enjoyed his main course of rabo de toro (oxtail stew) which was tender and juicy with fried potatoes. We were very full by the time dessert (tiramisu and cheesecake) was brought over. We were given a full bottle of house red which was included in the price. Total bill for lunch including a bottle of sparkling water and tips came to 30 eruos. I would still recommend a visit though my choice of lunch was disappointing probably because lunch was almost over and all the better dishes were gone. Service was great and I would give this restaurant a 3.5 star rating.

review_preview: After wandering around looking for somewhere to go, we dropped on Alhambra and decided to go in.  We were made welcome by the staff and on ordering a starter and 2 mains, the waitress advised  us that this was too much and that we only...
review_full: After wandering around looking for somewhere to go, we dropped on Alhambra and decided to go in. We were made welcome by the staff and on ordering a starter and 2 mains, the waitress advised us that this was too much and that we only needed 2 dishes. How glad were we for the advice. We had goats cheese to start, the portion was enormous and to be honest, a bit 'claggy'. We then had meatballs, which we love, again, the portion was massive. This left the meatballs a bit dry, smaller is definately better when it comes to meatballs as they tend to absorb the sauce better in our experience. For us, the Alhambra appears typical of lots of restaurants in Madrid, big, hearty meals, but sometimes, as in this case, going large was too much.

title_review: Great food with Madrileño touch. Not to be missed!
review_preview: La Antoñita is my favourite restaurant in Madrid. I have been there several times already and I believe it has everything you want from a restaurant: excellent and innovative food still with a Spanish or madrileño touch, nice and friendly service, very attentive yet not...
review_full: La Antoñita is my favourite restaurant in Madrid. I have been there several times already and I believe it has everything you want from a restaurant: excellent and innovative food still with a Spanish or madrileño touch, nice and friendly service, very attentive yet not invasive, great lively ambience any day of the week. I have recently celebrated my birthday on the back room and all my friends liked the food, the service and the venue extensively. It is a must-stop restaurant for anybody in Madrid, tourist or local. My favourite and not-to-be-missed tapas are: rabo de toro (definitely the best in town), the croquetas de mejillones tigre (tiger mussels croquette), the Barbecue sauce spare ribs (with pineapple, amazing!) and both the chocolate dessert and the soap dessert (the building used to be a soap manufactory and they have created a dessert to this former glory). If you are looking for an unforgettable experience with a Spanish and Madrid feeling, this is the place!

Cool decor and ambiance to start, staff was friendly and welcoming despite marginal english and our marginal spanish! We started with a few tapas, very good but a bit pricy at 6 euros. We ordered the grilled mixed veggies and "marinated mackeral and grilled tomatoes." The veggies were over cooked, oily and salty beyond belief, my fish turned out to be raw mackeral. I asked if it could be cooked or I could send it back. They said there was nothing that can be done because the menu never said it were cooked fish. Very small bits of fish as it were, upon trying it was sub par, and I love fish of all kinda, cooked or non. Bill also showed what we thought was complimentary bread given to us upon arriving to be 3 euro and my barely touched fish charged full price. Definitely a big disappointment for sure.

title_review: Delicious Galician food in the heart of Madrid!
review_preview: This is a very classic place that has delicious Galician food right in the heart of Madrid.Service is good and corteous, prices are affordable, food is tasty.and fresh. Very good wine selection.We had roasted pepper salad, garlic shrimp and vieyras. Delicious! Very nice...
review_full: This is a very classic place that has delicious Galician food right in the heart of Madrid. Service is good and corteous, prices are affordable, food is tasty.and fresh. Very good wine selection. We had roasted pepper salad, garlic shrimp and vieyras. Delicious! Very nice deserts. At the end, ask for a "chupito", a small portion of patxaran, a tasty liqueur. A reservation is recommended on Thursday, Friday, Saturday and Sunday. Totally worth a visit. Enjoy!

title_review: Unexpected surprise!! Amazing food, atmosphere and people!
review_preview: We were strolling down the street: Cava Baja, on recommendation of our bike guide earlier this day. La Antonita was different than the other restaurants in this neighborhood, it looked very nice and the woman in front of the restaurant didn't pull you in the...
review_full: We were strolling down the street: Cava Baja, on recommendation of our bike guide earlier this day. La Antonita was different than the other restaurants in this neighborhood, it looked very nice and the woman in front of the restaurant didn't pull you in the restaurant but just kindly said hello. She showed us the whole restaurant, which was beautiful! Underneath you could see the old city of the 12th century beneath the glass. We chose a table near the kitchen, we loved the cool wind and the atmosphere in this corner. The food was absolutely amazing! I absolutely loved the goat cheese with strawberries. I would highly recommend to visit this place, the staff is very very kind and decent and the food and place are great as well!

title_review: Excellent Modern Interpretation of Spanish Tapas
review_preview: This restaurant is a part of the Posada Del Dragon hotel.  There's an outdoor section which is the courtyard of the hotel and the indoor section which has a glass floor showing you parts of a historic wall that used to surround Madrid.  If you...
review_full: This restaurant is a part of the Posada Del Dragon hotel. There's an outdoor section which is the courtyard of the hotel and the indoor section which has a glass floor showing you parts of a historic wall that used to surround Madrid. If you want to try something a little different than the traditional tapas that you can get from literally thousands of Madrid restaurants, then this is a good choice, although it is a little pricier than traditional places. All of the tapas have modern interpretations and they use "foams" a lot (i.e., flavors of various food items concentrated into a foam). Service was excellent. Unfortunately, we had to buy bottled water although more traditional places would allow you to get regular Madrid water which is excellent. Everything we had was great.

title_review: When you're sick and tired of tapas
review_preview: After a week of tapas at almost every meal, we were looking for ANYTHING that wasn't cured or spreadable on bread. Our friend highly recommend Alhambra since it was close to the Westin Place - 10min walk at most. Even at 10pm (albeit Saturday night),...
review_full: After a week of tapas at almost every meal, we were looking for ANYTHING that wasn't cured or spreadable on bread.  Our friend highly recommend Alhambra since it was close to the Westin Place - 10min walk at most. Even at 10pm (albeit Saturday night), there were tons of people crowded at the bar and all the tables taken up. We were extremely surprised when one of the servers said it would only be a 10-15 min wait. We got a table in less than 10 mins and ordered drinks right away.  Drinks: reason for the crowded bar is that draft beer (at bar only) is dirt cheap ~1.5 euro! We ordered beers only - local draft and bottled - 3 euro each. Pro tip: magnum bottles of wine and cava available and cheap if you're super thirsty.  Food: got the most non-tapas/Spanish items on the menu and it was the BEST choice of the entire trip.  - GARLIC PRAWNS/SHRIMP - peeled shrimp literally swimming in sizzling butter and whole slices of garlic. So good that we used the sauce for our bread instead of the olive oil.  - MEAT PLATE FOR 2 - do not order anything else in addition to this. It will feed at least 3 people. It included 2 different types of sausages, chicken, veal, and bone in short ribs with a huge side of French fries and chimichurri sauce. Beware the meat sweats afterwards.  Overall: 46 euro for 2 people with 2 beers each and we were beyond stuffed. Best meal in Madrid (sorry tapas)!

review_preview: A proper, traditional sushi bar that will blow your mind. Make sure to pick a seat in the bar so that you can see all the action. There is only one menu, you get one or two starters and then a whole bunch of nigiris,...
review_full: A proper, traditional sushi bar that will blow your mind. Make sure to pick a seat in the bar so that you can see all the action. There is only one menu, you get one or two starters and then a whole bunch of nigiris, fresh and perfectly prepared. Now that 99 KO has closed, there aren't many true sushi bars to choose from in Madrid, and this one might be the best choice if you want a pure experience. Unlike Kabuki or Sushi 99, there is not a lot of fusion in the dishes. Pricewise, it's slightly cheaper than those two for a similar menu (i.e heavy on nigiris), and slightly less formal. If you want to get amazing sushi, this place is totally a can't miss.

review_preview: One of the better meals we had on our trip! We happened to stumble in to Lamiak as we got to Cava Baja around the time when places were setting up for business but Lamiak had already been opened for a while. It was quite...
review_full: One of the better meals we had on our trip! We happened to stumble in to Lamiak as we got to Cava Baja around the time when places were setting up for business but Lamiak had already been opened for a while. It was quite packed but we managed to squeeze our way in for some bar counter space. We had planned to just get a couple of drinks and then move on to dinner elsewhere but ended up hanging around once we saw some of the plates being served and so glad that we did! Unlike a few other places we've been to, the food was delightfully plated and looked delicious so we were sold on trying some out. We ordered the moussaka, smoked salmon, and a couple of variation of the bacalao. They were all wonderful. The drinks options were excellent as well and I loved how they were keeping tabs on all their patrons' orders on a huge sheet of paper behind the counter! Overall, prices were affordable and I would come back again if ever in Madrid.

Perhaps what makes the place particularly unique is the occasional entertainment that is offered from the "blind dinners" to the "micro-theater" . We participated in a recent "micro-theater" and even though it is in Spanish we thoroughly enjoyed it. Friend Majareta on Facebook to find a schedule of events.

title_review: Nice restaurant and food but greedy approach to guests
review_preview: Nice old restaurant with nice food. I loved the Manitas del cordero. Friendly and competent waiters. A nice evening until the meal was finished. But very disappointing after having eaten a large meal with starters, main and dessert, to be told to leave the restaurant...
review_full: Nice old restaurant with nice food. I loved the Manitas del cordero. Friendly and competent waiters. A nice evening until the meal was finished. But very disappointing after having eaten a large meal with starters, main and dessert, to be told to leave the restaurant before getting coffee and a brandy, because we only could have the table for two hours and other people were waiting. We suddenly felt badly treated. We were not told before the meal, that we only had two hours, and we told the waiter. He told us that we could have coffee then, but there was no time for the brandy. We said that we didn’t want coffee if it had to be in a hurry and asked for the bill. We were brought coffee anyway and thought therefore that it was on the house as a sort of compensation. But when we got the bill we were charged for the coffee. We have visited Madrid at least once a year for many years and have never before felt this time pressure or greed in restaurants in Madrid, where you usually are met with generosity and good manners, which we love about this city. An otherwise nice meal ended up been a not so good experience.

I don't know if it is because I'm American or the color of my skin, but this is among the worst service I've had in any restaurant. I got up and left while complaining about having been seated for 20 minutes and not having anyone come over. Nobody seemed to think it was a big deal as I was not asked to stay and when I looked back, the table just already being reset. Madrid has many great restaurants; I suggest you find another one.

title_review: You would never suspect the delicious meal you will have at Pelotari
review_preview: It was getting late and we did not have a reservation for dinner.We asked at the reception of our hotel and Borja suggested Pelotari, so we gave it a chance. It is a small restaurant with an unassuming appearance. The food turned out to...
review_full: It was getting late and we did not have a reservation for dinner. We asked at the reception of our hotel and Borja suggested Pelotari, so we gave it a chance. It is a small restaurant with an unassuming appearance. The food turned out to be great! The small dining room is decorated with images of pelotari, Basque men playing the sport called Pelota Vasca. Through a window, you can see the large grill with the hot coals and the flames beneath it. We could see a gentleman always busy, and he surely looked like an expert, moving very professionally in his kitchen. The menu offers many Basque dishes, and for some dishes you can order half a portion. Very convenient, if you are not too hungry or you want to try more different options! First they brought some bread and olives, and a few chistorras that were out of this world. Then we had a plate of excellent jamon and lomo ibérico and a tomate rosa (pink tomato) and bonito salad; afterwards we shared a rape a la brasa con patatas panadera (grilled fish with sautéed potatoes). We had the pleasure of watching the expert cook grilling our "rape". The fish was brought in small slices, incredibly flavorful and moist, and the potatoes were sliced and sautéed with onion. Awesome! For dessert we had the Pantxineta, a Basque dessert. The dough was formed by the thinest layers of puff pastry, filled with delicious pastry cream. A pleasure. We asked about the chef, and they told us that this gentleman has been cooking at Pelotari for decades. The owners wanted to sell, and he bought the restaurant. Now he continues to offer his Basque specialties, in his own restaurant. I hope he continues

title_review: A small and noisy restaurant, but well worth visiting for the food
review_preview: We booked for  3:30 ( the end of the lunch period). On arrival, the place was packed,noisy, they seated us in 10 minutes, but in a passage. We almost left. Then a good table was freed up and we moved. The only unfortunate part was...
review_full: We booked for 3:30 ( the end of the lunch period). On arrival, the place was packed,noisy, they seated us in 10 minutes, but in a passage. We almost left. Then a good table was freed up and we moved. The only unfortunate part was that next to us four old ladies were having a great (and loud) time. I ordered leeks (puerros) with goat cheese 12 Eur, wife ordered mushroom (setas) ragout with shrimp, 14 Eur. Both dishes were excellent..(Loys of mushroom) My only complaint was that there was too much oil in my dish, For dessert we had a chocolate cup (maceta) 6 Eur. That was also delectable. I had a glass of Rioja (3.20), the wife had large sparkling water (vichy catalan) (3.50). With bread and espresso total bill was 43 Eur. The waiter serving us spoke English and we certainly did not feel discriminated against. Two caveats, must book, and try for not the busiest part of a mealtime. Expect noise (loud discussions).

review_full: Wandering the streets of Madrid, we ventured in to Alhambra and were warmly welcomed and looked after by a waitress with plenty of charm and helpfulness, if limited English to match our limited Spanish. She even warned me about the dish of tripe which I was ordering, but which I was determined to enjoy willy-nilly. My mistake, however, was to order a "simple" salad as a starter; it was huge! I consume tomatoes every day, but this salad's tomato slices plus green leaves on top of mt tripe stew was all too much, for I could finish neither. My advice: stick to just a main course. Afterwards, if you are in the mood for a dessert, then, go for one; I reckon that you should then have a good chance of finishing that or most of it, at any rate. They show the total bill in euros and charge your card in euros, too. This I like lots and appreciate. Good for them and thanks to them. Enjoy a visit there.

review_preview: We had a lovely meal here, we both had Paella, which as well as looking really attractive and tasty stood up to it's appearance.  When we had been seated and ordered our drinks, the waiter gave us a tapas of chicken wings, we then ordered...
review_full: We had a lovely meal here, we both had Paella, which as well as looking really attractive and tasty stood up to it's appearance. When we had been seated and ordered our drinks, the waiter gave us a tapas of chicken wings, we then ordered the Paella which as always in Spain came with bread. The Paella was laden with prawns, crab, mussels, clams and had a large Langoustine on the top, the dish was very tasty and despite all the seafood was not too fishy tasting. The price was 8.50 euros each including the drink, bread and a coffee, so excellent value. All the food being served looked great and ample portions, I would recommend ordering little bits at a time as you can easily overeat. The service was excellent and the atmosphere too. I will definitely be eating here again next time I am in Madrid.

title_review: A foodie must see in Madrid, although expensive.
review_preview: I love this food market, it is the perfect place to experience the typical Madrid lifestyle while sampling some delicious food and wine. Although one of the more expensive food markets in Madrid, it is definitely worth a visit if only to stroll through the...
review_full: I love this food market, it is the perfect place to experience the typical Madrid lifestyle while sampling some delicious food and wine. Although one of the more expensive food markets in Madrid, it is definitely worth a visit if only to stroll through the stalls and enjoy the atmosphere. Try the bocadillo de calamari, a typical Madrid staple that consists of crispy fried calamari in a soft bread roll with alioli. Best enjoyed with a chilled glass of white. If you like Poke bowls, there is a stand which sells delicious ones and you will find stands selling delicious paella’s and cheese. A foodie must see in Madrid!

title_review: No trip to Madrid is complete without visiting this amazing market
review_preview: Madrid's major gastronomic market is an amazing experience and a place you just can't skip when you visit Madrid. There are plenty of stalls inside, where one can sample nearly every food the country has to offer, especially thinly sliced Jamón Ibérico, various cheeses, local...
review_full: Madrid's major gastronomic market is an amazing experience and a place you just can't skip when you visit Madrid. There are plenty of stalls inside, where one can sample nearly every food the country has to offer, especially thinly sliced Jamón Ibérico, various cheeses, local beers and great wines.  Can't rate it as excellent because it is overpriced (especially comparing to other places in Madrid, where the prices are very reasonable in general), but it is a fancy gourmet market after all and it is definitely worth visiting, even for a light snack. Although I wanted to try almost everything!

review_preview: Having flown in very early and spent the day walking around we decided to dine near our hotel. We booked for 9pm as recommended by the hotel who commented it was well known for its steaks. The service was top class. I had the special...
review_full: Having flown in very early and spent the day walking around we decided to dine near our hotel. We booked for 9pm as recommended by the hotel who commented it was well known for its steaks.  The service was top class. I had the special octopus as an entree, a half portion which was just as well as the portion was generous. It was very good. My wife had the local ham and again it was very good. Turning to the main course my wife had the smallest fillet which was cooked to perfection but was again a large portion. I was delighted by the special steak tartare which was made perfectly to my level of spice. All this rounded off with an inexpensive older Rioja which was selected from their list offered on an iPad which was a little different. The only sad thing, for them, is the restaurant was empty which is why I have marked it as very good rather than excellent.

The owner offered us a place at the bar which we snapped us because we really wanted to eat here!  We started with amazing margaritas: I had the Jamaican rose and my partner had a classic. These were really punchy and delicious, made by well-practiced hands! Our drinks also came with nachos and a beautiful tomato salsa. Later on in the meal we also ordered some Mexican beer, Pacifico, which was also very nice.  For food, we deferred entirely to the owner who explained that everything would be shared and took time to talk through the dishes with us. We had pulled pork tacos with red onion pickles, pork shoulder and guacamole tacos with a two chilli sauce and finally prawn and cheese quesadillas. Everything was exceptionally cooked and tasted sublime. I have not had Mexican food like this before and it was a real eye-opener. Our whole bill came to €55 which is very reasonable. The food is unmatched and the atmosphere is so cosy and relaxed. We were made to feel really welcome and the three members of staff seem very proud of what they have created here. Thank you for having us!

Total waste of money and a bad experience.. Wasn't worth €80!! Never again!!

review_full: We had dinner with a couple of friends last saturday at this restaurant. From reading the reviews I clearly expected more. This is a restaurant with three small rooms, so the feeling you get when you walk in is that it is very small with tables very close one to another. The decoration is dark and really not appealing at all.  Now the food, I know that basque cuisine can be exquisite but this was not the case. The shrimp and fried peppers appetizers were very good. The artichokes very average. We wanted to order the grilled fish to share but my husband asked to see it first. It took them a while and when they brought it on a plate they turned the fish's hear away, as if they didn't want us to see if it was fresh or not. In the end we ordered it and it was good, but the service had prepared us otherwise. We shared two desserts. One basque one, that I don't recall the name but is the only one on the menu, was really good, with a thin, crunchy crust and a very fresh tasty cream filling. The apple pie was a disappointment. Finally the service was very weird. They would come and stand on top of our table while we were in the middle of a discussion, and interrupt us to ask if we wanted to order anything else. And the lady in the end, when we paid the bill in two separate credit cards, charged the full amount in both! Then of course she corrected it, but all in all there are much better places to eat in Madrid.

review_full: My wife and I were taken to this hotel by business associates. For English readers of this review, locals know best! Not sure if this is in a tourist area as we were driven but it is worth taking a cab to. The restaurant felt traditional, certainly not pretentious and it felt very welcoming. The food was absolutely amazing in a simple no fuss sort of way. We had several courses (ordered for us) including an amazing salted cod that had the texture of thick cream and came with toast, fantastic. We then had a bream, it was cooked perfectly. I am now a bit of a food snob, I tend to cook so well at home that I only enjoy going to restaurants that create food that is impossible to reproduce. The exception is when I go to a restaurant that use great ingredients and keep things simple. I have previously reviewed Hooked in Windermere which is like this, now Pelotari joins it. I urge you to visit this restaurant, I doubt you will be disappointed.

title_review: Excellent Basque-Style Cooking (Asador), Great Quality Ingredients, Very Good Service
review_preview: Another great find on Tripadvisor.Being Spanish, having lived in Madrid and liking Basque-style food, I thought I had been to every decent Basque-style Asador worth the name in this city, and Pelotari was not on my list.  As things turned out,  I was clearly...
review_full: Another great find on Tripadvisor. Being Spanish, having lived in Madrid and liking Basque-style food, I thought I had been to every decent Basque-style Asador worth the name in this city, and Pelotari was not on my list. As things turned out, I was clearly missing one important name. I was entertaining a close friend who also loves Basque food and who insisted on going elsewhere (and paying the night's bill for having it his way). As I was visiting, he was kind enough to accept going to Pelotari, a place neither of us knew. The only condition was that dinner was on me. I'm picky with food quality, and Basque food leaves little room for concessions in that field, as food preparations are basic. You cannot disguise the quality of meat being served if it is just charcoal grilled and with some sea salt over it. No fancy sauces to hide bare bones reality. We settled for some appetizers. Jamón was exquisite, and salted anchovies were good without being great. A savoury and very convincing cod omelette completed the first round. Then came a big Chuleta (steak) to share. It was from out of this world. Meat was ably charcoal grilled, tender, savory, juicy. I'm running out of adjectives describing it. The BEST I've had in a long time. The meat was washed down with some nice Ribera del Duero wine. I found prices on the wine list to be adequate, whereas the wine selection was downright dull. Few nice bottles, and the one we picked was not available, so we had to settle for a second option. I guess the crisis has impacted the quality and amount of bottles restaurateurs keep in inventory these days. We had some desserts, not worth mentioning, and a not so great (our waiter pretended otherwise) gin & tonic to complete a great meal. To their credit, the cocktails were on the house, and not because we complained or anything. Service was competent and polite. It was a slow August Saturday when we visited, so I cannot judge how things will fare in busier days. Check came down to around 200 EUR, and wine was a third of that. Pricey, but money well spent. Dining room is on the classic side of things, and I did not like the lighting (no windows), but those were minor peccadilloes when thinking of how things fared altogether. We will definitely come back.

title_review: Supposed to be the best steaks in Madrid
review_preview: Our problem was that we didn't know they were a steak house so we didn't order meat. We had reserved online for 9 pm, but since we had only done it a few hours in advance, it didn't show up on their records. We had...
review_full: Our problem was that we didn't know they were a steak house so we didn't order meat. We had reserved online for 9 pm, but since we had only done it a few hours in advance, it didn't show up on their records. We had the email and text confirmation, of course, but it didn't matter because the place looked empty, which was a surprise. It turns out this is a really late place. When we left around 10:30 or so, the place was packed. A reservation is probably still a good idea. I ordered a half portion of delicious langostino salad and a half portion of pil-pil cod. The cod was ok, but pil-pil involved a thick tasteless sauce made from olive oil and something that made it thick and yellow. Not wonderful. My husband ordered a fresh, warm anchovy appetizer which he thought was ok, if a little bland. His main course was grilled Dover sole which was excellent. We had a nice bottle of Rioja wine for 25 euros. This restaurant is a bit more upscale than others we had been to in Madrid, so we expected the prices to be higher, but it was still just 90 euros, which right now is just over $100. The service was good and everyone was pleasant. They had at least one person who spoke decent English, so we didn't have to rely on our very limited Spanish. The theme of the place appeared to be jai alai based on the art on the walls, but it really had little to do with the food. It seemed like a warm and friendly place, in a fine dining kind of way.

The husband (front of the house) and wife (chef) who operate this restaurant do an excellent job is sourcing Spanish ingredients to create authentic Mexican flavors. Finding a restaurant open on Sunday evening can be a challenge in Spain. La Tomata is open and located in a really cute neighborhood. Juan, the husband, speaks fluent English which made the visit even more enjoyable for a non-Spanish speaker. He and his wife have created a very warm and inviting restaurant.

We will return here but select something disfferent next time and make a reservation first!

review_preview: We went to the Moharaj based on other TripAdvisor reviews. Being in Spain for the first time it would seem odd that we would seek a restaurant serving anything other than Spanish food, but I'm not too keen on pork and definitely not on seafood,...
review_full: We went to the Moharaj based on other TripAdvisor reviews. Being in Spain for the first time it would seem odd that we would seek a restaurant serving anything other than Spanish food, but I'm not too keen on pork and definitely not on seafood, so our options were limited. The Moharaj offered an alternative and we're familiar with the cuisine as it is prevalent in the area where we live in the U.S. The locale is clean and the staff is very attentive. We were seated quickly and our drink order was taken right away. The food at this restaurant ended up being the best Indian food I've ever had. The taste was not overpowering and they were willing to adapt the recipe to meet our individual tolerance for spiciness. The amount of food was more than adequate and the overall cost was a pleasant surprise, very affordable for a group of four adults (even after conversion to US dollars). I would have gladly eaten at this restaurant all five nights that I spent in Madrid. I would recommend it to anyone visiting the city. Sometimes the best gems are found in the most unexpected places and this one was one of them for me. Should I ever be in Madrid again, I will definitely seek out this restaurant. A special mention must be made on their Palak Paneer and the Rice Pilau. The latter is cooked to perfection!

title_review: Good, Solid Indian Food in a Great Setting, at a Great Price
review_preview: Four of us went here, and we were seated at a great table on the sidewalk outside the restaurant.  The neighborhood, Lavapies, is fun and lively.  The staff in the restaurant and very friendly, and their languages include both Spanish and English.  The menu is...
review_full: Four of us went here, and we were seated at a great table on the sidewalk outside the restaurant. The neighborhood, Lavapies, is fun and lively. The staff in the restaurant and very friendly, and their languages include both Spanish and English. The menu is long and features the usual suspects, all repeated for the beef, lamb, chicken, seafood, and vegetarian varieties. We had several dishes: palak paneer, dal makhni, rogan josh, a lamb curry; the vegetarian dishes were the best. The naan was excellent, as was the rice. We also had the samosas, which were very good. Between the four of us, and adding on a bottle of wine, the total bill came to about 60 euro. It's not the greatest Indian food I've ever had, but it was plenty good enough for us all to have a good time. www.riderbymyside.com

title_review: Atmosphere, great tapas, delicious vermouth and cañas
review_preview: This historic tavern/restaurant has a marker on the ground at the front that designates it as one of the older establishments in Madrid, and it is dripping with a quaint atmosphere and uniquely Madrid vibe.  It has a few low tables and stools in the...
review_full: This historic tavern/restaurant has a marker on the ground at the front that designates it as one of the older establishments in Madrid, and it is dripping with a quaint atmosphere and uniquely Madrid vibe. It has a few low tables and stools in the casual bar area at the front and a more formal restaurant in the back. The ubiquitous jamón legs were hanging at the back near the restaurant entrance, and an interesting little dog/wolf fountain was on the left wall near the front. We arrived early around 7:30 to avoid the crowds and bellied up to the bar for a few minutes before a table in the bar section opened up. We ordered the vermouth for our first drink and weren’t disappointed. We were told by a friend that it is pretty strong, but it tasted almost like a refreshing soft drink with no bubbles to me. Very good! It was served with pork rinds which we have never tasted before and were not my favorite, but one of my teenagers liked them. We moved on to cañas (small beers which were delicious) and tapas once we grabbed a table for five. The croquettas were actually the best I’ve tasted in Madrid. If you want to live like a Madrileño, go out a few hours later (8:30 pm or later) and enjoy the vibrant, joyful city life, but if you like to be less crowded and soak in the wonderful atmosphere with a little less noise, join the tourists earlier. We will be back!

review_preview: We were walking by this restaurant and looked at the Menu de Dia, my husband and I decided to have lunch here. When we walked in it was packed! The bar was packed, the tables to the side were occupied and the restaurant in the...
review_full: We were walking by this restaurant and looked at the Menu de Dia, my husband and I decided to have lunch here. When we walked in it was packed! The bar was packed, the tables to the side were occupied and the restaurant in the back was also packed. We didn’t have reservations and one of the friendly waiters told us to wait at the bar and we had a good chance of eating lunch there. So we had a glass of wine and a glass of cava. We waited around 35 minutes. We were not disappointed! He fideo was so good! The second plate is enormous! I wish we would have shared! This is a typical Madrid meal, and from what we were told this isn’t served everyday. This place is awesome! Especially Alvaro Martinez Marín who was very friendly, helpful, and attentive! Can’t wait to visit Casa Alberto next year!

review_preview: My husband, son and I all love this tapas bar. My son and I had visited on our first trip to Madrid last year and went twice. On this trip, it was the first place we took my husband whose enthusiasm equaled ours so much...
review_full: My husband, son and I all love this tapas bar. My son and I had visited on our first trip to Madrid last year and went twice. On this trip, it was the first place we took my husband whose enthusiasm equaled ours so much so we dragged our friends from Madrid the next night who admitted Casa Alberto has the best croquetas that they have had. While there are many tourists – there are many local people who come as well. The ambiance is very convivial. The waiter and barman are exceptionally professional mixed with a lot of fun. Prices are very reasonable. But what is most shocking is the quality of the food and the uniqueness of the menu. Honestly – it would take at least 10 visits to try everything. And absolutely everything we have tried there has been 5 stars. We have only visited the bar area as the restaurant menu did not appeal to us. Don’t be frightened of the wait for a small bar table – the people watching and Vermut makes the time fly. For us this is an absolute must in Madrid.

title_review: Best meal I’ve had in Spain so far!
review_preview: With a front bar and casual tapas, and a back formal dining, I really lucked out by choosing Casa Alberto. I was looking for non-fried tapas, and something beyond toast and prosciutto. As a solo traveler eating at a table by myself can be intimidating...
review_full: With a front bar and casual tapas, and a back formal dining, I really lucked out by choosing Casa Alberto. I was looking for non-fried tapas, and something beyond toast and prosciutto. As a solo traveler eating at a table by myself can be intimidating but the atmosphere was super warm and inviting, and my waiter was incredibly nice. When you order a drink you have a choice of chips, olives, or pork rinds; I got the green olives. Ordered a bread basket (only 1€) and Rabo Estofado (tail stew).  For real, best thing I’ve eaten so far.  So rich and full of flavor, served with potatoes and falling off the bone. I was full after the first one but kept eating (serves 2). Two glasses of wine later my total bill was 17,60€ and totally worth it. Really close to Plaza Mayor and Antón Martín metro station. Would definitely recommend.

review_preview: We had a reservation and were seated quickly, which is important to note because the evening before we had attempted dinner here and were told it was at least an hour or more for a table. We found the waitstaff to be friendly, fun  and...
review_full: We had a reservation and were seated quickly, which is important to note because the evening before we had attempted dinner here and were told it was at least an hour or more for a table. We found the waitstaff to be friendly, fun and efficient, and loved the fried stuffed olive tapas. Sadly, that was the highlight of the meal. My salad of grilled peaches substituted canned peaches, without any warning or explanation, and the result was so far from the expected appetizer that it put a damper on the rest of the meal. We had two main fish entrees, each of which were utterly forgettable, yet expensive. We didn't linger for dessert, although the bar, always lively, was compelling. Maybe it was an off night for the kitchen, but in the future I would go for drinks and tapas at the bar and not bother with a full meal.

review_preview: If you’re a local, they treat you with respect - if not, they are rude. I have traveled extensively and am sitting in a restaurant just up the street from Cafe Alberto and this place knows how to treat you (and has better food).Alberto’s...
review_full: If you’re a local, they treat you with respect - if not, they are rude. I have traveled extensively and am sitting in a restaurant just up the street from Cafe Alberto and this place knows how to treat you (and has better food). title_review: Great for vegetarians ! Hit the spot!
review_preview: As another reviewer mentioned, the decor was not the greatest, but the food was excellent and the service good. We were first served two large Papadum. I love starting an Indian meal with papadum. It's crispy and salty and not filling. A great palate cleanser....
review_full: As another reviewer mentioned, the decor was not the greatest, but the food was excellent and the service good. We were first served two large Papadum. I love starting an Indian meal with papadum. It's crispy and salty and not filling. A great palate cleanser. We are vegetarians so we ordered the Aloo Ghobi and the Chana Masala. We also asked for it to be medium spicy since we like a little kick. The dishes came with a few hot green peppers mixed in. By cutting up the green peppers, we could make it as spicy as we wanted. The Aloo Ghobi was one of the best I've had and with the extra hot pepper, perfect. My husband really loved the Chana Masala as well. I highly recommend this place (and ask for the medium spicy if you prefer spicy food as I do!)

title_review: Good curries - lack ambiance on a Tuesday evening in April!
review_preview: There were only two occupied tables. The moghul special (lamb) was mild and surprising, the vandaloo (lamb) hot and spicy. It was a shame that the place was so empty on a Tuesday. I passed this restaurant on a Sunday and I vaguely remember it...
review_full: There were only two occupied tables. The moghul special (lamb) was mild and surprising, the vandaloo (lamb) hot and spicy. It was a shame that the place was so empty on a Tuesday. I passed this restaurant on a Sunday and I vaguely remember it being full - as were all the neighbourhood restaurants. I would recommend it for the food, but next time, I would seat away from the fish tank - a very slight rank smell (water filters needs cleaning perhaps?). The decor - as described in other reviews - is what I remember from India, it has authenticity, and yes, I would return for the food!

review_preview: This is a great Indian restaurant serving authentic Indian food.  It has a real local feel to it and is not at all pretentious.  From an extensive menu, we ordered gobi aloo and chickpea masala.  We asked our server, who was also the owner, for...
review_full: This is a great Indian restaurant serving authentic Indian food. It has a real local feel to it and is not at all pretentious. From an extensive menu, we ordered gobi aloo and chickpea masala. We asked our server, who was also the owner, for both dishes to be spiced up a bit extra. He was happy to oblige and both tasted just right. He chatted with us further about Indian food and spices and the evolution of his business over the past 8 years. It was an interesting discussion. Prices are very reasonable too. We enjoyed everything about our meal here and highly recommend this friendly place to other travelers seeking authentic Indian food in Madrid.

review_preview: Saw positive reviews on this restaurant and liked the menu.  Specifically I'm a big Oxtail fan and will try it in any country I visit.Made reservations via the internet since we were flying in that day and it was Saturday night.  As such we...
review_full: Saw positive reviews on this restaurant and liked the menu. Specifically I'm a big Oxtail fan and will try it in any country I visit. Made reservations via the internet since we were flying in that day and it was Saturday night. As such we wanted an early dinner (8pm). Showed up promptly and were told it would be 10 minutes before they could seat us, so they just left us standing there looking at the empty restaurant with the tapas bar behind us full of people. Finally took us to our table, but apparently a walk up with an 11 party group came in right after us and the waiter said 'oh we need to put you at another table since we need to pull these tables together'. Remember we had a reservation. Two other tables for two were set up, one by the hallway entry, which was very undesirable and another in the back corner which was quite nice. The waiter agreed to put us back there but actually said 'will you be done by 9:45 since that table is reserved'. So, we have a reservation, an 11 table walk up boots us out of our planned table and we are told we can't have the nice table if we are going to linger. One waiter working at this point. Fortunately we got an order in before he started with the 11 person table (not locals but Americans like us but with 5 children in the party). He had brought us some bread which is all we had with our drinks until a 2nd waiter turned up and suddenly brought out a little appetizer to both our table and the 11 party table. They had just finished ordering, but for us our food came out one minute later, so clearly we were ignored for 15 to 20 minutes and the service that should normally be provided was not. We had the meatballs and the ox tail. The meatballs were good. The ox tails, which as mentioned I've had many times, were ok at best. Decent flavor, but only three of them, which is significant since they are mostly bone and at least in many places a very cheap 'cut' of meat. When cooked properly the meat is supposed to fall off the bone. Two of them did but the third could barely be cut off. So a very disappointing dish. Based on our experience we would not go back.

Got seated by 10, they were turning away those w/o reservations. My husband and I shared a dinner salad. It was ok but swimming in oil and vinegar. Being brave I ordered the oxtail since I had seen it recommended in a posting. It came w a side of french fries. It was ok, tasted just like a rump roast I make in the crockpot at home. Husband ordered the cod topped with shrimp. The shrimp was soggy and the chunk of fish was very raw in the middle. Not sure if it was supposed to be so we sent it back so they cooked it a little bit more so it was only a little raw. The atmosphere and nice service were really what this place is about... The food, I just don't get it.

One fault was the coffee machine was not working but we were assured this was only temporary, but I felt rather than finding some sort of solution they decided just not to bother. It sounds like a big complaint but it was no big deal for us really and I just had another beer to finish. I would definitely recommend and use this restaurant again. Staff were friendly and efficient.

review_preview: As a brit living in Madrid it is hard to find that comfort food that is just like home. Well i can tell you that this is amazing!From the fresh naan bread and the creamy sauces and good quality meat, perfectly cooked rice and...
review_full: As a brit living in Madrid it is hard to find that comfort food that is just like home. Well i can tell you that this is amazing! From the fresh naan bread and the creamy sauces and good quality meat, perfectly cooked rice and even the no frills papadums and dips. The service was friendly and efficient and with the weather still being nice we were able to sit outside and enjoy. Their "Menu del Día" is a great offer, we various options. I went for the 12.50€ which included vegetable pakoras or onion bhajis and then a curry of choice (Korma for me) and then rice or naan. You also get a drink of choice and a coffee or tea after. The a la carte menu had so many options and prices were very good compared to other places offering the same in Madrid. A must visit for that "just like home" feel!

review_preview: When the taxi took me to the door and I had my first look, I thought that this couldn't possibly be the place people had raved about and told me to go to. It's homely and plain with red gingham paper tablecloths and green chair...
review_full: When the taxi took me to the door and I had my first look, I thought that this couldn't possibly be the place people had raved about and told me to go to. It's homely and plain with red gingham paper tablecloths and green chair coverings. I thought I'd play safe and have onion bhajee and Chicken Jalfrezi. The bhajee were great and came with some super sauces and condiments, the Jalfrezi was perfect too as was the rice. One sole downside was that the main arrived just seconds after I had finished the bhajee. I would have preferred a bit of time to digest the starter. I waited a while after the meal and decided to have a kulfi. This was good too, I ordered the mango version. The place was full of people from the British Council and expats, with whom I spoke. That must be a good advert. With a half bottle of wine, plus an extra glass, the bill was just shy of 30 Euros. A selection of flacons of "digestifs" was served at the end of the meal and it was left up to me how much I wanted to pour into my glass, which is a nice touch. I did not take advantage! The service was absolutely fine and attentive but not obtrusive. The area the restaurant is in is worth visiting in itself as it is full of winding, cobbled streets and hidden gems all over.  I'd go back if I returned to Madrid.

review_full: Love it! Everything was so wonderful, that if I had my way - we'd eat there breakfast lunch and dinner every one of the three days we were in Madrid.  This is the place for foodies - tons of varieties, the prices are not outrageous (and hey, you're on vacation, right?) and the food is fresh.  We had a plate of ten different kinds of cheeses (don't miss the Spanish Manchego, which is a kind of sharp cheddar-like cheese - delish!), different kinds of appetizers, sampler plate of olives and pickles, meat pies, and of course Desserts but I could go back again and again just for their delicious sangria which was surprisingly white (I thought sangria were made with red wine). It was so refreshing and delicious! Go outside and have a delicious cup of coffee/cappuccino/espresso in the plaza outside, and do some fantastic people watching... I miss that so much..

review_preview: Madrid has a lot of Indian/Pakistani/Bangladeshi restaurants to choose from and some are very good. I have tried so many I've lost track. But, hands down Moharaj on Calle Buenavista is the best. Since finding this little gem three years a go I have had...
review_full: Madrid has a lot of Indian/Pakistani/Bangladeshi restaurants to choose from and some are very good. I have tried so many I've lost track. But, hands down Moharaj on Calle Buenavista is the best. Since finding this little gem three years a go I have had no need or desire to find my Masala, Curry, Rogan Josh, Korma, etc. anywhere else. My husband and I even ordered delivery every Sunday for 2 years - the food always arrived in under an hour and was always hot and just as good as in the restaurant. It is small but it is clean and the staff are very kind and friendly and the food --- is so good it is unforgettable. Since moving away from Madrid it is the only restaurant we always go to when we are in town My absolute favorite meal is the Prawns Masala (Gambas Masala) with some garlic naan. Go. You will love it.

review_full: Searched for a Indian restaurant in Madrid as we were tired of ham, cheese, tomatoes, bread and Olive oil! Moharaj got good reviews and was within walking distance from our hotel. So glad we stopped here. We ate street side. We were the first to arrive for dinner (9pm) but the place filled up shortly there after. We were concerned about bland "Americanized" flavor and asked for spicy (even though our dishes aren't normally made spicy). The waiter laughed at us and ensured us the food would have flavor. The food did have flavor, but just to make sure he brought us some spicy mixture to add to our meal. A teeny tiny taste of the paste starts off sweet and slowly but surely turns hot. It was a nice added flavor in very controlled amounts! The owner or manager came out to talk with us about Indian food and flavor and treated us to a mango drink. It was a great meal.

That night happened to have been our 36th anniversary, and we could not have spent it at a nicer place.

review_preview: We went to this restaurant based on the TA reviews…mistake.We should have realised what we were in for when after sitting down and ordering 4 doble cervezas we were subsequently delivered 4 ½ litres of warm, cloudy beer. And it went downhill from there...
review_full: We went to this restaurant based on the TA reviews…mistake. We should have realised what we were in for when after sitting down and ordering 4 doble cervezas we were subsequently delivered 4 ½ litres of warm, cloudy beer. And it went downhill from there with a waiter straight from Fawlty Towers. Our entree of onion bhaji was dry and tasteless with no accompanying sauce. And of the mains only the chicken jalfrezi was really acceptable. The dhal was so gluggy it would have stuck to the bowl if turned upside down and the tandoori lamb tikka had no tandoori flavour nor mint sauce. And with the garlic naan no one could taste any garlic etc etc. There are many many Indian restaurants in this neighbourhood…chose another…they couldn’t be any worse.

title_review: A great lively night out with friends
review_preview: We were staying with friends at the  Catalonia Gran Via Hote, Madrid as part of an excellent Riviera Travel tour to Madrid, Salamanca and Toledo. One evening whilst looking at nearby restaurants for our evening meal we found the Taberna Alambra. We were immediately impressed...
review_full: We were staying with friends at the Catalonia Gran Via Hote, Madrid as part of an excellent Riviera Travel tour to Madrid, Salamanca and Toledo. One evening whilst looking at nearby restaurants for our evening meal we found the Taberna Alambra. We were immediately impressed by the rustic Spanish decor and the lively atmosphere. The staff couldn't have been more hospitable, even when under great pressure as the place filled up. Drinks were served with free appetizers. The food was great, particularly the pork dishes, and the local wine was good. We returned there later in the week and had another great evening. We were surprised to be recognised by staff. To round off our meal we had a had a huge jug of their excellent sangria and when it came to paying the bill we were given a large glass of sangria each for free.

review_preview: We decided to go here due to good reviews on Tripadvisor and they lived up to the expectations. They started us off with some complementary starters. I continued with chicken tikka masala, which was recommended in the menu. I haven't eaten a lot of Indian...
review_full: We decided to go here due to good reviews on Tripadvisor and they lived up to the expectations. They started us off with some complementary starters. I continued with chicken tikka masala, which was recommended in the menu. I haven't eaten a lot of Indian food before, but this was delicious. The sauce might be a bit too sweet for some. After we finished with our main course, we also got a complementary mango puree, which was also quite nice. The main waiter was probably the nicest server I've ever had the pleasure of dealing with - he was extremely friendly and helpful. If you plan on eating in the evening, I would suggest coming a bit early as they were packed later on. Overall, I recommend this restaurant.

review_preview: We gratefully stumbled upon Taberna Alhambra while walking around Plaza del Sol.  Perfect place to get a typical Spanish meal, reasonably priced and the food delicious! We ended up going there 3 times during my 2 week stay.  There are actually 2 different sides to...
review_full: We gratefully stumbled upon Taberna Alhambra while walking around Plaza del Sol. Perfect place to get a typical Spanish meal, reasonably priced and the food delicious! We ended up going there 3 times during my 2 week stay. There are actually 2 different sides to Alhambra - one side is for food and the other side, they call it a "grill" where they feature grilled meats. BOTH are excellent, but we preferred the "grill" side. You cannot go wrong with the salads, the typical egg/potatoes/prosciutto dish, the pork chops, the meat, the seafood lobster rice. The french fries were to DIE for! On the "grill" side, during lunch, they even provided a complimentary appetizer of the most succulent grilled chicken wings with the bread! Sangria was amazing. The included apple pie dessert put our U.S. apple pie to shame with the fresh apples that just made us wish for yet another piece, but couldn't because we were too embarrassed! You'll be glad you went and so will your wallet!

title_review: Typical elbow to elbow bar area
review_preview: We were walking around town and decided to check this place out.  We hit it at just the right time, as the second table inside the front door was open, and nobody was at the bar.  The guy behind the bar took our drink and...
review_full: We were walking around town and decided to check this place out. We hit it at just the right time, as the second table inside the front door was open, and nobody was at the bar. The guy behind the bar took our drink and food order, and passed our drinks to me across the bar. As the food we ordered was ready, another guy brought the dishes to our table. As we were eating and drinking, the bar area filled up, and was elbow to elbow by the time we were done. We had the albondigas (meatballs) and croquetas de jamon, and both were yummy. And the tap vermouth is something to be treasured while in town, as you can't find that in the States. It was a fun, local experience.

title_review: Meh food and, sad to say, rude waiters
review_preview: I usually read Trip Advisor reviews before choosing a restaurant and I usually start by reading those of people who didn’t have a good experience. And normally I discount those who say that the staff was rude because peoples’ ideas of rudeness vary. Well, in...
review_full: I usually read Trip Advisor reviews before choosing a restaurant and I usually start by reading those of people who didn’t have a good experience. And normally I discount those who say that the staff was rude because peoples’ ideas of rudeness vary. Well, in this case, I should have paid attention. My husband and I are Americans who currently live in Barcelona but are relocating to Madrid for work. We have lived much of the past 40 years in Europe and travel extensively so we are not newbies who don’t know what to expect. And the staff at Casa Alberto was rude. For no reason. We were extremely taken aback but decided to stay to see if the food made up for it. It didn’t. It wasn’t bad but it was, well, meh.  So I would recommend that you give this restaurant a miss. You can get better service which, in my experience, is the norm in Spain, combined with more innovative and interesting food, for the same price.  And I would like to apologize for doubting those of you who had already eaten there and had to experience the same rudeness!

review_preview: It has all the makings of a place that's just got that little bit too big for its boots.  The building itself is an absolute beauty, from the red and gold façade that beckons you in, and the olde worlde bar area that wouldn't look...
review_full: It has all the makings of a place that's just got that little bit too big for its boots. The building itself is an absolute beauty, from the red and gold façade that beckons you in, and the olde worlde bar area that wouldn't look out of place in a film. There's a plaque on the wall of the bar making the (somewhat dubious) claim that Cervantes completed one of his novels there, as well as the alarm-bell-ringing sight of celebrities who've stopped by. A good rule of thumb: if a place prides itself on the famous people who've ventured inside, it's probably mediocre. And so it proved. We wandered in and made a beeline for a table that had just become free, hoping to order drinks and tapas. We were quickly escorted away from those seats by a maítre d', hovering between bar and restaurant, who quickly informed us that he'd reserved that spot for someone else. Fair enough, of course, but we'd had no way of knowing that there was a wait. The kicker came when I approached him straight afterwards, asking him if there was a waiting list for a seat. "Yes, young man, there are people waiting" came the brusque reply, and off he walked, oblivious to our less than subtle indications that we were hoping to sit down at some point. So to the bar we went. The guy behind it, it must be said, was significantly more affable than his colleague had been. Still not quite service with a smile, but polite enough. We ordered a couple of vermouths (which were very refreshing, but at €2.60 each, were the most expensive we'd had anywhere in Madrid) and cast a glance at the tapas menu. Immediately it became clear why Alberto and co. did not list the prices of the food on their website: it's severely overpriced.  Madrid is an affordable city, with a host of cheap yet delicious eateries, so you would do an awful lot better than to eat here. Standing at the bar, I came within an inch of ordering a tortilla, until I saw someone at the bar request one, only to be served a paltry slice of something that looked as if it had been sat stewing all day on the bar. That fellow punter saved me a princely €7. You'd also expect that a bowl of six meatballs priced at €10 would have to be seriously high quality. But no sooner had someone else ordered them than you could hear the pinging of the microwave warming them up in full view of the bar. To charge so much and unashamedly deliver a microwaved meal demonstrates a complete contempt for the customer.  Oh and in case you were tempted to bypass the bar and head into the restaurant, many of the menu items are exactly the same, only with even higher prices. I wouldn't bet on the food not coming out of a microwave in there either.  We polished off our vermouths and took our custom elsewhere. If you're in the neighbourhood and fancy a bite to eat, head around the corner to Casa González instead. The fresh Spanish produce, beautiful wine list and fantastic service made that one of the finds of our trip.

review_preview: We read lots of reviews for this place, and really wanted to love it. The prices were pretty good, the food looked and smelled amazing, and we were looking forward to eating. Apparently we shouldn't have come on a weekend, though. A table for two...
review_full: We read lots of reviews for this place, and really wanted to love it. The prices were pretty good, the food looked and smelled amazing, and we were looking forward to eating. Apparently we shouldn't have come on a weekend, though. A table for two took almost 30 minutes. Our waitress was rude and impatient, and lectured us angrily for taking so long to decide what we wanted, explaining that we should hurry up because they were busy and if we didn't know what we wanted right away, we were taking up a table where other people could be eating. We had been sitting for less than a minute. This is the only place I've been in Madrid where ordering a drink before deciding on food earned me a glare and "That's it? Why did you ask for a table?" The food WAS excellent, and everyone else was friendly, but the constant scowls and dirty looks from the waitress ruined it.

title_review: Beautiful, ornate interior and lively energy at the bar plus thoughtful, interesting food...
review_preview: Casa Alberto has real old world elegance and atmosphere but serves plates that are thoughtful, bold and delicious. We started with a righteous plate of chicharrones and ordered an ox tail-stuffed fried pepper and a "brownie" of morcilla topped with a goat-cheese croquet. We were...
review_full: Casa Alberto has real old world elegance and atmosphere but serves plates that are thoughtful, bold and delicious. We started with a righteous plate of chicharrones and ordered an ox tail-stuffed fried pepper and a "brownie" of morcilla topped with a goat-cheese croquet. We were starting to see a pattern where tapas tend to be much larger than we expected, but still these dishes were superb. Standing at the bar, trying out our pitiful Spanish on the bartender we decided we love Casa Alberto. Later in the week we returned for albondegas and a plate of ham. Like many of the places in the area, Casa Alberto seems to do a lot of its business via tourists, but the atmosphere at the bar still feels like a glimpse into the way it's always been done. The staff may be a bit "over" the tourists but we noticed a different, slightly warmer reaction when we came back a second time, which is something we look for when traveling. We planned a third visit but they were closed.
