review_preview: Calle Victoria it is worth a stroll just to see the artistic tilework along the street.  We decided to go here because of the intriguing photo on the outside of the building of a woman with a gun in her hand, open blouse and a...
review_full: Calle Victoria it is worth a stroll just to see the artistic tilework along the street. We decided to go here because of the intriguing photo on the outside of the building of a woman with a gun in her hand, open blouse and a compelling face that had us making up many stories as we ate. We started with some of the servers recommendations. The chicken drummettes and wings were amazing, cooked to a perfection in a garlic cumin red wine sauce. The cold tomato soup (Gazpacho) was served with a cream base as it is in most of Spain. It was garnished with Iberian ham bits and shredded cheese. The tomatoes had no tell tale been in the refrigerator taste, which means it was very fresh, still cold and very satisfying. The 10 garlic prawns were enormous and perfectly cooked, not mushy and overcooked like so many places. They were the best we had in all of Spain. We then got the day's special, a huge steak which my husband loved. I was under the impression it would be chunks of beef in sauce but it was an inch thick and seasoned with garlic and grilled medium rare. We had this with some good local beer and were completely satiated. The ambiance of the place, the friendly server, extremely LOW prices and good food gives this place a high recommendation. See my photos.

review_preview: My partner and I went to this restaurant based on TA reviews and were not disappointed.  It is very convenient to Puerta del Sol.  Our waiter was very helpful, even suggesting appropriate amounts to order.  Although his English was limited, he wanted to know what...
review_full: My partner and I went to this restaurant based on TA reviews and were not disappointed. It is very convenient to Puerta del Sol. Our waiter was very helpful, even suggesting appropriate amounts to order. Although his English was limited, he wanted to know what the English names were of some of the vegetables we ordered. We ordered grilled garlic shrimp, grilled vegetables, and some sort of grilled beef. The shrimp came out sizzling in olive oil in a ceramic dish and were cooked perfectly. This dish was so good, I asked the server how it was prepared so I could fix it at home. The vegetables were perfectly done as well. While the meat was very tasty, it was a tad chewy. We finished off this great meal with the apple tort, more or less equivalent to our apple pie. All in all, this was one of our better meals in Madrid.

title_review: Can't miss this authentic Spanish tavern
review_preview: OMFG!! This place is phenomenal!!!Old school tavern in Madrid just a short walk away from Atocha train station and Reina Sofía museum. It was packed on a random Thursday afternoon so I waited at the bar while a table cleared up for lunch. I...
review_full: OMFG!! This place is phenomenal!!! Old school tavern in Madrid just a short walk away from Atocha train station and Reina Sofía museum. It was packed on a random Thursday afternoon so I waited at the bar while a table cleared up for lunch.  I was immediately greeted by a small plate of fried pork rinds and a glass of house red wine. The wait went by pretty fast sube 15 minutes) and I was shown to my table.  In true European (and especially Spanish) fashion, the dining room was a bit too tight compared to what were used to in America but it doesn't feel crowded. If anything, it's cozy.  I knew I wanted the beef belly stew (callos a la madrileña) so I told the waiter to choose a starter for me. He suggested a wonderful plate of hummus and roasted artichoke hearts which was amazing. And beautifully presented. Light but flavorful!  Then came the entree... wow. I was blown away with how good the callos were here. Seriously. Perfectly cooked together with a small blood sausage, spanish chorizo and bacon. I'm still thinking about it... And what better way to end it than with a nicely prepared espresso and a slice of chocolate and hazelnut cake? I kid you not, every bite into this cake tasted exactly like a Ferrero Rocher chocolate. Inclusive of the crunchy bits and soft filling. Amazing.  I will be coming back with my family next week. And will certainly be redoing it whenever I'm back in Madrid. Don't miss this place if you're in the city.

By Madrilena friend called it authentic and it certainly felt like that, so really enjoyed the ambience and food. Mollejas (lamb sweetbreads one of my favourites and simply but well done), baby squid with chili/tomato jam which was the weak point - there should have been some chili in it, then excellent beans with partridge - perfectly cooked. Mature friendly service. Would happily return for a tapas like lunch but doubt the kitchen could sustain a dinner.

review_preview: I dropped into this restaurant while staying nearby and I am glad I did. If you are in the area and are trying to figure out where to eat, you need to visit here for a meal.The food was excellent (I had the best...
review_full: I dropped into this restaurant while staying nearby and I am glad I did. If you are in the area and are trying to figure out where to eat, you need to visit here for a meal. The food was excellent (I had the best cut of beef from my trip at this restaurant) and the service was good too. The restaurant has literally been around for hundreds of years and it has the character and atmosphere to prove it. This restaurant is busy in the evenings, but any wait to get a table is well worth it. Whether you’re a family or just having a night out for two, you’ll enjoy Casa Alberto. Also, while I know some Spanish, those I traveled with did not know any—yet they had no issues of troubles ordering dishes. We all enjoyed our meals and agreed that any future trips to Madrid would have to include a stop at this restaurant again.

title_review: Great food and Atmosphere in wonderful location.
review_preview: Just back from Madrid - dinner here at the suggestion of our B&B owner.Packed full restaurant in eclectic neighborhood.  All fresh items on the menu.  Reninded me of a neighborhood NY eatery.  So many locals eating there.  Also, lots of interesting wall decorations since...
review_full: Just back from Madrid - dinner here at the suggestion of our B&B owner. Packed full restaurant in eclectic neighborhood. All fresh items on the menu. Reninded me of a neighborhood NY eatery. So many locals eating there. Also, lots of interesting wall decorations since time of opening. We limited ourselves to one fine dinner meal in each city and Casa Alberto was our pick in Madrid. Dinner was not cheap by US standards.....64 Euros / $84 for two with reasnable wine and no dessert but one of the fine and memorable meals of our trip. Lots of other authentic restaurants on the same street around Lope De Vega but this one was the best! Waiters scurrying about added to the positive armosphere.

review_preview: My wife and I happened across Casa Alberto as we sought a place to eat after visiting the Prado. Not wanting tapas in the afternoon, we sat in the restaurant to order a dinner. The staff was very friendly with one waiter who spoke sufficient...
review_full: My wife and I happened across Casa Alberto as we sought a place to eat after visiting the Prado. Not wanting tapas in the afternoon, we sat in the restaurant to order a dinner. The staff was very friendly with one waiter who spoke sufficient English was available to assist us. The decor was warm and welcoming. We both ordered seafood. The restaurant had a nice selection from which to choose from their menu including seafood, steak, ox tail stew, lamb chops and other delights. I ordered the cod which was well prepared with a pimento sauce and onion straws. Very nice plate. We wife had the hake with garlic prawns, again a well-prepared and tasty meal. Although a little on the pricy side, we enjoyed the food. We paid 66 Euros with a beer, half-bottle of house wine, bread and an appetizer with our main meals.We would return to try their tapas.

review_full: We ate here after visiting the Prado museum, it's a quick enough walk. We arrived early and we were able to relax and sit at the tables in front eating bread, olives and having cold drinks until the back tables opened up. The restaurant itself has been around a long time, serving bullfighters, literary types and of course, tourists. The place filled up quickly and apparently stays that way all night. We enjoyed our Gazpacho, salad, meatballs, sorbet, wine, coffee and more. I'm getting hungry writing this. We paid a total of $72 for all of that, not bad. You can spend much more but we were very satisfied. The waiters were friendly and the service was very good although our Spanish is limited to only a few words. We wanted to eat in the back but you could certainly sit in the front and eat tapas without a problem. Enjoyed it very much and would go back if we lived there....

title_review: Great food, great atmosphere, lovely little restaurant.
review_preview: I have eaten at Casa Alberto twice now, in July and August '12 and both times the food was great. I deliberately went back there tonight to see if it was as good as last time, and it was. Although the prices are relatively high,...
review_full: I have eaten at Casa Alberto twice now, in July and August '12 and both times the food was great. I deliberately went back there tonight to see if it was as good as last time, and it was. Although the prices are relatively high, I still rate the food as really good value, as it basically tastes great.  When not in the UK I usually consider how popular a restaurant is with local people as a good marker of quality, and it looks very popular with the people of Madrid, so thumbs up there too. I had the fried vegetables with prawns to start, and it is delicious (although fans of the Catherine Tate show may be bemoaning "battered veg" as it is a kind of tempura!) I had the beef tenderloin to follow, very good as well. If I had a down point, the service can be a bit slow, but it is busy! Overall, well worth a visit next time you're in Madrid.

review_preview: We decided to try this place because it was close to our hotel, relatively inexpensive and had decent reviews on here.  I wish we hadn't.  The sangria was good and we were served a chicken wing appetizer that was sketchy.  Our group had salad and...
review_full: We decided to try this place because it was close to our hotel, relatively inexpensive and had decent reviews on here. I wish we hadn't. The sangria was good and we were served a chicken wing appetizer that was sketchy. Our group had salad and paella which was filling, but unremarkable. I ordered a steak (medium) which was cold and red in places, did not have much meat around the bones and made me ill.  Be very careful what you order here. Maybe drinks and happy hour tapas might be ok... but avoid the heavier fare.

review_preview: The food was fantastic, once we got it. There was one poor waiter serving the whole restaurant, so he was totally rushed off his feet. He did a good job considering, but it made the experience a little painful. One of our dishes was forgotten,...
review_full: The food was fantastic, once we got it. There was one poor waiter serving the whole restaurant, so he was totally rushed off his feet. He did a good job considering, but it made the experience a little painful. One of our dishes was forgotten, and arrived after we'd finished the rest and weren't really hungry. It was brilliant though - breaded and fried aubergine with alioli. We also enjoyed a tomato and egg on bread thing. And sangria. It's clear to see why this place has such mixed reviews - but treat it with patience and the food is worth it!

review_preview: The first time we came in here, we were delighted at the friendly service, hearty portions, and reasonable prices. Unfortunately, I felt pretty ill afterwards. I hadn't had that much to eat, but I assumed I felt ill from having drunk a couple of beers...
review_full: The first time we came in here, we were delighted at the friendly service, hearty portions, and reasonable prices. Unfortunately, I felt pretty ill afterwards. I hadn't had that much to eat, but I assumed I felt ill from having drunk a couple of beers and travelling. We went back later in the vacation. Big mistake. Again, we only had a couple of dishes, and no alcohol, but I felt really bloated for hours afterwards, and I thought I was going to vomit. The restaurant is full of 20 year old American students pretending that they are having an adventure because they are allowed to drink, and other tourists who have been lured in by the decent Tripadvisor and Yelp reviews. Don't be one of them!

title_review: It´s a Food Market that words cannot properly describe ... fabulous!
review_preview: Mercado San Miguel is a renovated food market that has been transformed into a foodie´s delight.  At every step, every corner, every turn you are overwhelmed by the smell, by presentation, by the atmosphere!  Located literally steps from Plaza Mayor you almost want to keep...
review_full: Mercado San Miguel is a renovated food market that has been transformed into a foodie´s delight. At every step, every corner, every turn you are overwhelmed by the smell, by presentation, by the atmosphere! Located literally steps from Plaza Mayor you almost want to keep it a secret but know full well that it would be impossible. But, don´t tell everybody --- only friends and foodies you know who will delight in this experience! From oysters and champage, to cafes with melted m&ms with macaroons every colour and flavour possible - to cheese counters and fresh pasta ... or just fabulous tapas!  On the downside .... busy, busy place! But worth it!
